25842and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3222b-2(d)) is amended by

25843striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

25844SEC. 7120. NEW BEGINNING FOR TRIBAL STUDENTS.

25845

25846 Subtitle G of the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and

25847Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3221 et seq.) is amended by adding

25848at the end the following:

25849

25850[[Page 132 STAT. 4791]]

25851

25852``SEC. 1450. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 3222e.&gt;&gt; NEW BEGINNING FOR TRIBAL

25853 STUDENTS.

25854

25855 ``(a) Definitions.--In this section:

25856 ``(1) Indian tribe.--The term `Indian tribe' has the meaning

25857 given such term in section 4 of the Indian Self-Determination

25858 and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C. 5304)).

25859 ``(2) Land-grant college or university.--The term `land-

25860 grant college or university' includes a 1994 Institution (as

25861 defined in section 532 of the Equity in Educational Land-Grant

25862 Status Act of 1994 (Public Law 103-382; 7 U.S.C. 301 note)).

25863 ``(3) Tribal student.--The term `Tribal student' means a

25864 student at a land-grant college or university that is a member

25865 of an Indian tribe.

25866

25867 ``(b) New Beginning Initiative.--

25868 ``(1) Authorization.--The Secretary may make competitive

25869 grants to land-grant colleges and universities to provide

25870 identifiable support specifically targeted for Tribal students.

25871 ``(2) Application.--A land-grant college or university that

25872 desires to receive a grant under this section shall submit an

25873 application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and

25874 accompanied by such information as the Secretary may require.

25875 ``(3) Use of funds.--A land-grant college or university that

25876 receives a grant under this section shall use the grant funds to

25877 support Tribal students through--

25878 ``(A) recruiting;

25879 ``(B) tuition and related fees;

25880 ``(C) experiential learning; and

25881 ``(D) student services, including--

25882 ``(i) tutoring;

25883 ``(ii) counseling;

25884 ``(iii) academic advising; and

25885 ``(iv) other student services that would

25886 increase the retention and graduation rate of

25887 Tribal students enrolled at the land-grant college

25888 or university, as determined by the Secretary.

25889 ``(4) Matching funds.--A land-grant college or university

25890 that receives a grant under this section shall provide matching

25891 funds toward the cost of carrying out the activities described

25892 in this section in an amount equal to not less than 100 percent

25893 of the grant award.

25894 ``(5) Maximum amount per state.--No State shall receive,

25895 through grants made under this section to land-grant colleges

25896 and universities located in the State, more than $500,000 per

25897 year.

25898

25899 ``(c) Report.--Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of

25900this section, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on Agriculture

25901of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture,

25902Nutrition, and Forestry and the Committee on Indian Affairs of the

25903Senate a report that includes an itemized list of grant funds

25904distributed under this section, including the specific form of

25905assistance provided under subsection (b)(3), and the number of Tribal

25906students assisted and the graduation rate of Tribal students at land-

25907grant colleges and universities receiving grants under this section.

25908

25909[[Page 132 STAT. 4792]]

25910

25911 ``(d) Authorization of Appropriation.--There is authorized to be

25912appropriated to carry out this section $5,000,000 for each of fiscal

25913years 2019 through 2023.''.

25914SEC. 7121. HISPANIC-SERVING INSTITUTIONS.

25915

25916 Section 1455(c) of the National Agricultural Research, Extension,

25917and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3241(c)) is amended by

25918striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

25919SEC. 7122. BINATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT.

25920

25921 Section 1458(e) of the National Agricultural Research, Extension,

25922and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3291(e)) is amended--

25923 (1) in the subsection heading, by striking ``Full Payment of

25924 Funds Made Available for Certain'' and inserting ``Certain'' ;

25925 (2) by striking ``Notwithstanding'' and inserting the

25926 following:

25927 ``(1) Full payment of funds.--Notwithstanding'';

25928 (3) in paragraph (1) (as so designated)--

25929 (A) by striking ``Israel-United States'' and

25930 inserting ``United States-Israel''; and

25931 (B) by inserting ``(referred to in this subsection

25932 as the `BARD Fund')'' after ``Development Fund''; and

25933 (4) by adding at the end the following:

25934 ``(2) Activities.--Activities under the BARD Fund to promote

25935 and support agricultural research and development that are of

25936 mutual benefit to the United States and Israel shall--

25937 ``(A) accelerate the demonstration, development, and

25938 application of agricultural solutions resulting from or

25939 relating to BARD Fund programs, including BARD Fund-

25940 sponsored research and innovations in drip irrigation,

25941 pesticides, aquaculture, livestock, poultry, disease

25942 control, and farm equipment; and

25943 ``(B) encourage research carried out by

25944 governmental, nongovernmental, and private entities,

25945 including through collaboration with colleges and

25946 universities, research institutions, and the private

25947 sector.''.

25948SEC. 7123. PARTNERSHIPS TO BUILD CAPACITY IN INTERNATIONAL

25949 AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH, EXTENSION, AND

25950 TEACHING.

25951

25952 The National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy

25953Act of 1977 is amended by inserting after section 1458 (7 U.S.C. 3291)

25954the following:

25955``SEC. 1458A. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 3292.&gt;&gt; PARTNERSHIPS TO BUILD

25956 CAPACITY IN INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL

25957 RESEARCH, EXTENSION, AND TEACHING.

25958

25959 ``(a) Definitions.--In this section:

25960 ``(1) 1862 institution; 1890 institution; 1994

25961 institution.--The terms `1862 Institution', `1890 Institution',

25962 and `1994 Institution' have the meanings given the terms in

25963 section 2 of the Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education

25964 Reform Act of 1998 (7 U.S.C. 7601).

25965 ``(2) Covered institution.--The term `covered Institution'

25966 means--

25967 ``(A) an 1862 Institution;

25968

25969[[Page 132 STAT. 4793]]

25970

25971 ``(B) an 1890 Institution;

25972 ``(C) a 1994 Institution;

25973 ``(D) an NLGCA Institution;

25974 ``(E) a Hispanic-serving agricultural college or

25975 university; and

25976 ``(F) a cooperating forestry school.

25977 ``(3) Developing country.--The term `developing country'

25978 means a country, as determined by the Secretary using a gross

25979 national income per capita test selected by the Secretary.

25980 ``(4) International partner institution.--The term

25981 `international partner institution' means an agricultural higher

25982 education institution in a developing country that is

25983 performing, or desiring to perform, activities similar to

25984 agricultural research, extension, and teaching activities

25985 carried out through covered Institutions in the United States.

25986

25987 ``(b) Authority of the Secretary.--The Secretary may promote

25988cooperation and coordination between covered Institutions and

25989international partner institutions through--

25990 ``(1) improving extension by--

25991 ``(A) encouraging the exchange of research materials

25992 and results between covered Institutions and

25993 international partner institutions;

25994 ``(B) facilitating the broad dissemination of

25995 agricultural research through extension; and

25996 ``(C) assisting with efforts to plan and initiate

25997 extension services in developing countries;

25998 ``(2) improving agricultural research by--

25999 ``(A) in partnership with international partner

26000 institutions, encouraging research that addresses

26001 problems affecting food production and security, human

26002 nutrition, agriculture, forestry, livestock, and

26003 fisheries, including local challenges; and

26004 ``(B) supporting and strengthening national

26005 agricultural research systems in developing countries;

26006 ``(3) supporting the participation of covered Institutions

26007 in programs of international organizations, such as the United

26008 Nations, the World Bank, regional development banks, and

26009 international agricultural research centers;

26010 ``(4) improving agricultural teaching and education by--

26011 ``(A) in partnership with international partner

26012 institutions, supporting education and teaching relating

26013 to food and agricultural sciences, including technical

26014 assistance, degree training, research collaborations,

26015 classroom instruction, workforce training, and education

26016 programs; and

26017 ``(B) assisting with efforts to increase student

26018 capacity, including to encourage equitable access for

26019 women and other underserved populations, at

26020 international partner institutions by promoting

26021 partnerships with, and improving the capacity of,

26022 covered Institutions;

26023 ``(5) assisting covered Institutions in strengthening their

26024 capacity for food, agricultural, and related research,

26025 extension, and teaching programs relevant to agricultural

26026 development activities in developing countries to promote the

26027 application of new technology to improve education delivery;

26028 ``(6) providing support for the internationalization of

26029 resident instruction programs of covered Institutions;

26030

26031[[Page 132 STAT. 4794]]

26032

26033 ``(7) establishing a program, to be coordinated by the

26034 Director of the National Institute of Food and Agriculture and

26035 the Administrator of the Foreign Agricultural Service, to place

26036 interns from covered Institutions in, or in service to benefit,

26037 developing countries; and

26038 ``(8) establishing a program to provide fellowships to

26039 students at covered Institutions to study at foreign

26040 agricultural colleges and universities.

26041

26042 ``(c) Enhancing Linkages.--The Secretary shall enhance the linkages

26043among covered Institutions, the Federal Government, international

26044research centers, counterpart research, extension, and teaching agencies

26045and institutions in developed countries and developing countries--

26046 ``(1) to carry out the activities described in subsection

26047 (b); and

26048 ``(2) to make a substantial contribution to the cause of

26049 improved food and agricultural progress throughout the world.

26050

26051 ``(d) Authorization of Appropriations.--There is authorized to be

26052appropriated to carry out this section $10,000,000 for each of fiscal

26053years 2019 through 2023.''.

26054SEC. 7124. COMPETITIVE GRANTS FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL

26055 SCIENCE AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

26056

26057 Section 1459A(c)(2) of the National Agricultural Research,

26058Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3292b(c)(2)) is

26059amended by striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

26060SEC. 7125. LIMITATION ON INDIRECT COSTS FOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH,

26061 EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS.

26062

26063 Section 1462 of the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and

26064Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3310) is amended--

26065 (1) in subsection (a), by striking ``22 percent'' and

26066 inserting ``30 percent'';

26067 (2) in subsection (b), by striking ``Subsection (a)'' and

26068 inserting ``Subsections (a) and (c)''; and

26069 (3) by adding at the end the following:

26070

26071 ``(c) Treatment of Subgrants.--In the case of a grant described in

26072subsection (a), the limitation on indirect costs specified in such

26073subsection shall be applied to both the initial grant award and any

26074subgrant of the Federal funds provided under the initial grant award so

26075that the total of all indirect costs charged against the total of the

26076Federal funds provided under the initial grant award does not exceed

26077such limitation.''.

26078SEC. 7126. RESEARCH EQUIPMENT GRANTS.

26079

26080 The National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy

26081Act of 1977 is amended by inserting after section 1462 (7 U.S.C. 3310)

26082the following new section:

26083``SEC. 1462A. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 3310a.&gt;&gt; RESEARCH EQUIPMENT GRANTS.

26084

26085 ``(a) In General.--The Secretary may make competitive grants for the

26086acquisition of special purpose scientific research equipment for use in

26087the food and agricultural sciences programs of eligible institutions.

26088 ``(b) Maximum Amount.--The amount of a grant made to an eligible

26089institution under this section may not exceed $500,000.

26090

26091[[Page 132 STAT. 4795]]

26092

26093 ``(c) Prohibition on Charge or Equipment as Indirect Costs.--The

26094cost of acquisition or depreciation of equipment purchased with a grant

26095under this section shall not be--

26096 ``(1) charged as an indirect cost against another Federal

26097 grant; or

26098 ``(2) included as part of the indirect cost pool for

26099 purposes of calculating the indirect cost rate of an eligible

26100 institution.

26101

26102 ``(d) Eligible Institutions Defined.--In this section, the term

26103`eligible institution' means--

26104 ``(1) a college or university; or

26105 ``(2) a State cooperative institution.

26106

26107 ``(e) Authorization of Appropriations.--There is authorized to be

26108appropriated to carry out this section $5,000,000 for each of fiscal

26109years 2019 through 2023.''.

26113Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3311) is amended by striking

26114``2018'' each place it appears in subsections (a) and (b) and inserting

26115``2023''.

26120``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

26121SEC. 7129. SUPPLEMENTAL AND ALTERNATIVE CROPS; HEMP.

26124Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3319d) is amended--

26125 (1) in subsection (a)--

26127 (B) by striking ``crops,'' and inserting ``crops

26128 (including canola),'';

26129 (2) in subsection (b)--

26130 (A) by inserting ``for agronomic rotational purposes

26131 and as a habitat for honey bees and other pollinators''

26132 after ``alternative crops''; and

26133 (B) by striking ``commodities whose'' and all that

26134 follows through the period at the end and inserting

26135 ``commodities.'';

26136 (3) in subsection (c)(3)(E), by inserting ``(including hemp

26137 (as defined in section 297A of the Agricultural Marketing Act of

26138 1946))'' after ``material''; and

26139 (4) in subsection (e)--

26140 (A) in paragraph (1), by striking ``and'' at the

26141 end;

26142 (B) in paragraph (2), by striking the period at the

26143 end and inserting ``; and''; and

26144 (C) by adding at the end the following new

26145 paragraph:

26146 ``(3) $2,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 through

26147 2023.''.

26154 (B) in clause (iii), by striking the period at the

26155 end and inserting ``; and''; and

26156 (C) by adding at the end the following:

26157

26158[[Page 132 STAT. 4796]]

26159

26160 ``(iv) precision agriculture.''; and

26161 (2) in subsection (d), by striking ``2008 through 2012'' and

26162 inserting ``2019 through 2023''.

26163SEC. 7131. CAPACITY BUILDING GRANTS FOR NLGCA INSTITUTIONS.

26164

26165 Section 1473F(b) of the National Agricultural Research, Extension,

26166and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3319i(b)) is amended by

26167striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

26168SEC. 7132. AGRICULTURE ADVANCED RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY

26169 PILOT.

26170

26171 Subtitle K of the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and

26172Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3310 et seq.) is amended by adding

26173at the end the following:

26174``SEC. 1473H. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 3319k.&gt;&gt; AGRICULTURE ADVANCED

26175 RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY

26176 PILOT.

26177

26178 ``(a) Definitions.--In this section:

26179 ``(1) Advanced research and development.--The term `advanced

26180 research and development' means research and development

26181 activities used to address research challenges in agriculture

26182 and food through--

26183 ``(A) targeted acceleration of novel, early stage

26184 innovative agricultural research with promising

26185 technology applications and products; or

26186 ``(B) development of qualified products and

26187 projects, agricultural technologies, or innovative

26188 research tools, which may include--

26189 ``(i) prototype testing, preclinical

26190 development, or field experimental use;

26191 ``(ii) assessing and assisting with product

26192 approval, clearance, or need for a license under

26193 an applicable law, as determined by the Director;

26194 or

26195 ``(iii) manufacturing and commercialization of

26196 a product.

26197 ``(2) Agricultural technology.--The term `agricultural

26198 technology' means machinery and other equipment engineered for

26199 an applicable and novel use in agriculture, natural resources,

26200 and food relating to the research and development of qualified

26201 products and projects.

26202 ``(3) Director.--The term `Director' means the Director of

26203 the Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Authority

26204 established under subsection (b)(1).

26205 ``(4) Other transaction.--The term `other transaction' means

26206 a transaction other than a procurement contract, grant, or

26207 cooperative agreement, including a transaction described in

26208 subsection (b)(6)(A).

26209 ``(5) Person.--The term `person' means--

26210 ``(A) an individual;

26211 ``(B) a partnership;

26212 ``(C) a corporation;

26213 ``(D) an association;

26214 ``(E) an entity;

26215 ``(F) a public or private corporation;

26216 ``(G) a Federal, State, or local government agency

26217 or department; and

26218

26219[[Page 132 STAT. 4797]]

26220

26221 ``(H) an institution of higher education, including

26222 a land-grant college or university and a non-land-grant

26223 college of agriculture.

26224 ``(6) Qualified product or project.--The term `qualified

26225 product or project' means--

26226 ``(A) engineering, mechanization, or technology

26227 improvements that will address challenges relating to

26228 growing, harvesting, handling, processing, storing,

26229 packing, and distribution of agricultural products;

26230 ``(B) plant disease or plant pest recovery

26231 countermeasures to intentional or unintentional

26232 biological threats (including naturally occurring

26233 threats), including--

26234 ``(i) replacement or resistant plant cultivars

26235 or varieties;

26236 ``(ii) other enhanced management strategies,

26237 including novel chemical, biological, or cultural

26238 approaches; or

26239 ``(iii) diagnostic or surveillance technology;

26240 and

26241 ``(C) veterinary countermeasures to intentional or

26242 unintentional biological threats (including naturally

26243 occurring threats), including--

26244 ``(i) animal vaccine or therapeutic products

26245 (including anti-infective products); or

26246 ``(ii) diagnostic or surveillance technology.

26247 ``(7) Research tool.--The term `research tool' means a

26248 device, technology, procedure, biological material, reagent,

26249 computer system, computer software, or analytical technique that

26250 is developed to assist in the discovery, development, or

26251 manufacture of a qualified product or project.

26252

26253 ``(b) Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Authority.--

26254 ``(1) Establishment.--There is established within the

26255 Department of Agriculture a pilot program that shall be known as

26256 the Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Authority

26257 (referred to in this section as the `AGARDA') to carry out

26258 advanced research and development.

26259 ``(2) Goals.--The goals of the AGARDA are--

26260 ``(A) to develop and deploy advanced solutions to

26261 prevent, prepare, and protect against unintentional and

26262 intentional threats to agriculture and food in the

26263 United States;

26264 ``(B) to overcome barriers in the development of

26265 agricultural technologies, research tools, and qualified

26266 products and projects that enhance export

26267 competitiveness, environmental sustainability, and

26268 resilience to extreme weather;

26269 ``(C) to ensure that the United States maintains and

26270 enhances its position as a leader in developing and

26271 deploying agricultural technologies, research tools, and

26272 qualified projects and products that increase economic

26273 opportunities and security for farmers, ranchers, and

26274 rural communities; and

26275 ``(D) to undertake advanced research and development

26276 in areas in which industry by itself is not likely to do

26277 so because of the technological or financial

26278 uncertainty.

26279 ``(3) Leadership.--

26280 ``(A) In general.--The AGARDA shall be a component

26281 of the Office of the Chief Scientist.

26282 ``(B) Director.--

26283

26284[[Page 132 STAT. 4798]]

26285

26286 ``(i) In general.--The AGARDA shall be headed

26287 by a Director, who shall be appointed by the Chief

26288 Scientist.

26289 ``(ii) Qualifications.--The Director shall be

26290 an individual who, by reason of professional

26291 background and experience, is exceptionally

26292 qualified to advise the Chief Scientist on, and

26293 manage advanced research and development programs

26294 and other matters pertaining to--

26295 ``(I) qualified products and

26296 projects;

26297 ``(II) agricultural technologies;

26298 ``(III) research tools; and

26299 ``(IV) challenges relating to the

26300 matters described in subclauses (I)

26301 through (III).

26302 ``(iii) Relationship within the department of

26303 agriculture.--The Director shall report to the

26304 Chief Scientist.

26305 ``(4) Duties.--To achieve the goals described in paragraph

26306 (2), the Secretary, acting through the Director, shall

26307 accelerate advanced research and development by--

26308 ``(A) identifying and promoting advances in basic

26309 sciences;

26310 ``(B) translating scientific discoveries and

26311 inventions into technological innovations;

26312 ``(C) collaborating with other agencies, relevant

26313 industries, academia, international agencies, the

26314 Foundation for Food and Agriculture Research, and other

26315 relevant persons to carry out the goals described in

26316 paragraph (2), including convening, at a minimum, annual

26317 meetings or working groups to demonstrate the operation

26318 and effectiveness of advanced research and development

26319 of qualified products and projects, agricultural

26320 technologies, and research tools;

26321 ``(D) conducting ongoing searches for, and support

26322 calls for, potential advanced research and development

26323 of agricultural technologies, qualified products and

26324 projects, and research tools;

26325 ``(E) awarding grants and entering into contracts,

26326 cooperative agreements, or other transactions under

26327 paragraph (6) for advanced research and development of

26328 agricultural technology, qualified products and

26329 projects, and research tools;

26330 ``(F) establishing issue-based multidisciplinary

26331 teams to reduce the time and cost of solving specific

26332 problems that--

26333 ``(i) are composed of representatives from

26334 Federal and State agencies, professional groups,

26335 academia, and industry;

26336 ``(ii) seek novel and effective solutions; and

26337 ``(iii) encourage data sharing and translation

26338 of research to field use; and

26339 ``(G) serving as a resource for interested persons

26340 regarding requirements under relevant laws that impact

26341 the development, commercialization, and technology

26342 transfer of qualified products and projects,

26343 agricultural technologies, and research tools.

26344 ``(5) Priority.--In awarding grants and entering into

26345 contracts, cooperative agreements, or other transactions under

26346

26347[[Page 132 STAT. 4799]]

26348

26349 paragraph (4)(E), the Secretary shall give priority to projects

26350 that accelerate the advanced research and development of

26351 qualified products and projects that--

26352 ``(A) address critical research and development

26353 needs for technology for specialty crops; or

26354 ``(B) prevent, protect, and prepare against

26355 intentional and unintentional threats to agriculture and

26356 food.

26357 ``(6) Other transaction authorities.--

26358 ``(A) In general.--In carrying out the pilot program

26359 under this section, the Secretary shall have the

26360 authority to enter into other transactions in the same

26361 manner and subject to the same terms and conditions as

26362 transactions that the Secretary of Defense may enter

26363 into under section 2371 of title 10, United States Code.

26364 ``(B) Scope.--The authority of the Secretary to

26365 enter into contracts, cooperative agreements, and other

26366 transactions under this subsection shall be in addition

26367 to the authorities under this Act and title I of the

26368 Department of Agriculture and Related Agencies

26369 Appropriation Act, 1964 (7 U.S.C. 3318a), to use

26370 contracts, cooperative agreements, and grants in

26371 carrying out the pilot program under this section.

26372 ``(C) Guidelines.--The Secretary shall establish

26373 guidelines regarding the use of the authority under

26374 subparagraph (A).

26375 ``(D) Technology transfer.--In entering into other

26376 transactions, the Secretary may negotiate terms for

26377 technology transfer in the same manner as a Federal

26378 laboratory under paragraphs (1) through (4) of section

26379 12(b) of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act

26380 of 1980 (15 U.S.C. 3710a(b)).

26381 ``(7) Availability of data.--

26382 ``(A) In general.--The Secretary shall require that,

26383 as a condition of being awarded a contract or grant or

26384 entering into a cooperative agreement or other

26385 transaction under paragraph (4)(E), a person shall make

26386 available to the Secretary on an ongoing basis, and

26387 submit to the Secretary on request of the Secretary, all

26388 data relating to or resulting from the activities

26389 carried out by the person pursuant to this section.

26390 ``(B) Exemption from disclosure.--

26391 ``(i) In general.--This subparagraph shall be

26392 considered a statute described in section

26393 552(b)(3)(B) of title 5, United States Code.

26394 ``(ii) Exemption.--The following information

26395 shall be exempt from disclosure under section 552

26396 of title 5, United States Code, and withheld from

26397 the public:

26398 ``(I) Specific technical data or

26399 scientific information that is created

26400 or obtained under this section that

26401 reveals significant and not otherwise

26402 publicly known vulnerabilities of

26403 existing agriculture and food defenses

26404 against biological, chemical, nuclear,

26405 or radiological threats.

26406 ``(II) Trade secrets or commercial

26407 or financial information that is

26408 privileged or confidential (within the

26409 meaning of section 552(b)(4) of title 5,

26410 United States Code) and obtained in the

26411 conduct

26412

26413[[Page 132 STAT. 4800]]

26414

26415 of research or as a result of activities

26416 under this section from a non-Federal

26417 party participating in a contract,

26418 grant, cooperative agreement, or other

26419 transaction under this section.

26420 ``(iii) Limitation.--Information that results

26421 from research and development activities conducted

26422 under this section and that would be a trade

26423 secret or commercial or financial information that

26424 is privileged or confidential if the information

26425 had been obtained from a non-Federal party

26426 participating in a cooperative agreement or other

26427 transaction shall be withheld from disclosure

26428 under subchapter II of chapter 5 of title 5,

26429 United States Code, for 5 years.

26430 ``(8) Milestone-based payments allowed.--In awarding

26431 contracts and grants and entering into cooperative agreements or

26432 other transactions under paragraph (4)(E), the Secretary may--

26433 ``(A) use milestone-based awards and payments; and

26434 ``(B) terminate a project for not meeting technical

26435 milestones.

26436 ``(9) Use of existing personnel authorities.--In carrying

26437 out this subsection, the Secretary may appoint highly qualified

26438 individuals to scientific or professional positions on the same

26439 terms and conditions as provided in subsections (b)(3), (b)(4),

26440 (c), (d), (e), and (f) of section 620 of the Agricultural

26441 Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act of 1998 (7 U.S.C.

26442 7657).

26443 ``(10) Report and evaluation.--

26444 ``(A) Report.--The Secretary shall submit to the

26445 Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives

26446 and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and

26447 Forestry of the Senate an annual report examining the

26448 actions undertaken and results generated by the AGARDA.

26449 ``(B) Evaluation.--After the date on which the

26450 AGARDA has been in operation for 3 years, the

26451 Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct

26452 an evaluation--

26453 ``(i) to be completed and submitted to the

26454 Committee on Agriculture of the House of

26455 Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture,

26456 Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate not later

26457 than 1 year after the date on which the

26458 Comptroller General began conducting the

26459 evaluation;

26460 ``(ii) describing the extent to which the

26461 AGARDA is achieving the goals described in

26462 paragraph (2); and

26463 ``(iii) including a recommendation on whether

26464 the AGARDA should be continued, terminated, or

26465 expanded.

26466

26467 ``(c) Strategic Plan.--

26468 ``(1) In general.--Not later than 360 days after the date of

26469 enactment of this section, the Secretary shall develop and make

26470 publicly available a strategic plan describing the strategic

26471 vision that the AGARDA shall use--

26472 ``(A) to make determinations for future investments

26473 during the period of effectiveness of this section; and

26474 ``(B) to achieve the goals described in subsection

26475 (b)(2).

26476 ``(2) Dissemination.--The Secretary shall disseminate the

26477 information contained in the strategic plan under paragraph

26478

26479[[Page 132 STAT. 4801]]

26480

26481 (1) to persons who may have the capacity to substantially

26482 contribute to the activities described in that strategic plan.

26483 ``(3) Coordination; consultation.--The Secretary shall--

26484 ``(A) update and coordinate the strategic

26485 coordination plan under section 221(d)(7) of the

26486 Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994

26487 with the strategic plan developed under paragraph (1)

26488 for activities relating to agriculture and food defense

26489 countermeasure development and procurement; and

26490 ``(B) in developing the strategic plan under

26491 paragraph (1), consult with--

26492 ``(i) the National Agricultural Research,

26493 Extension, Education, and Economics Advisory Board

26494 established under section 1408(a);

26495 ``(ii) the specialty crops committee

26496 established under section 1408A(a)(1);

26497 ``(iii) relevant agriculture research agencies

26498 of the Federal Government;

26499 ``(iv) the National Academies of Sciences,

26500 Engineering, and Medicine;

26501 ``(v) the National Veterinary Stockpile Intra-

26502 Government Advisory Committee for Strategic

26503 Steering; and

26504 ``(vi) other appropriate parties, as

26505 determined by the Secretary.

26506

26507 ``(d) Funds.--

26508 ``(1) Establishment.--There is established in the Treasury

26509 the Agriculture Advanced Research and Development Fund, which

26510 shall be administered by the Secretary, acting through the

26511 Director--

26512 ``(A) for the purpose of carrying out this section;

26513 and

26514 ``(B) in the same manner and subject to the same

26515 terms and conditions as are applicable to the Secretary

26516 of Defense under section 2371 of title 10, United States

26517 Code.

26518 ``(2) Deposits into fund.--

26519 ``(A) In general.--The Secretary, acting through the

26520 Director, may accept and deposit into the Fund monies

26521 received pursuant to cost recovery, contribution, or

26522 royalty payments under a contract, grant, cooperative

26523 agreement, or other transaction under this section.

26524 ``(B) Availability of amounts in fund.--Amounts

26525 deposited into the fund shall remain available until

26526 expended, without further appropriation, and may be used

26527 to carry out the purposes of this section.

26528 ``(C) Clarification.--Nothing in this paragraph

26529 authorizes the use of the funds of the Commodity Credit

26530 Corporation to carry out this section.

26531 ``(3) Funding.--In addition to funds otherwise deposited in

26532 the Fund under paragraph (1) or (2), there is authorized to be

26533 appropriated to the Fund $50,000,000 for each of fiscal years

26534 2019 through 2023, to remain available until expended.

26535

26536 ``(e) Termination of Effectiveness.--

26537 ``(1) In general.--Except as provided under paragraph (2),

26538 the authority provided by this section terminates on the date

26539 that is 5 years after the date of the enactment of the

26540 Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018.

26541

26542[[Page 132 STAT. 4802]]

26543

26544 ``(2) Exceptions.--Paragraph (1) shall not apply with

26545 respect to--

26546 ``(A) subsection (b)(7)(B); and

26547 ``(B) grants awarded or contracts, cooperative

26548 agreements, or other transactions entered into before

26549 the end of the 5-year period referred to in such

26550 clause.''.

26562 RESPONSE.

26565Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3351) is amended--

26568 end;

26570 end and inserting ``; and''; and

26578 ``competitive grants'';

26581 cooperative agreements''; and

26583 paragraph:

26585 Research, Education, and Economics mission area of the

26586 Department that protect the integrity, reliability,

26587 sustainability, and profitability of the food and agricultural

26588 system of the United States against biosecurity threats from

26589 pests, diseases, contaminants, and disasters.''.

26628SEC. 7205. NATIONAL STRATEGIC GERMPLASM AND CULTIVAR COLLECTION

26629 ASSESSMENT AND UTILIZATION PLAN.

26632Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5841(d)) is amended--

26633 (1) in paragraph (5), by striking ``and'' at the end;

26635 (3) by inserting after paragraph (5) the following:

26636 ``(6) develop and implement a national strategic germplasm

26637 and cultivar collection assessment and utilization plan that

26638 takes into consideration the resources and research necessary to

26639 address the significant backlog of characterization and

26640 maintenance of existing accessions considered to be critical to

26641 preserve the viability of, and public access to, germplasm and

26642 cultivars; and''.

26645Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5842) is amended by adding

26646at the end the following:

26648plan described in section 1632(d)(6), the Secretary shall make the plan

26649available to the public.''.

26650SEC. 7206. NATIONAL GENETICS RESOURCES PROGRAM.

26651

26652 (a) Advisory Council.--Section 1634 of the Food, Agriculture,

26653Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5843) is amended--

26654 (1) in subsection (a)--

26655 (A) in the first sentence, by striking ``The

26656 Secretary'' and inserting the following:

26657 ``(1) In general.--The Secretary'';

26658 (B) in the second sentence of paragraph (1) (as so

26659 designated), by striking ``The advisory'' and inserting

26660 the following:

26661 ``(2) Membership.--The advisory'';

26662

26663[[Page 132 STAT. 4804]]

26664

26665 (C) in paragraph (2) (as so designated), by striking

26666 ``nine'' and inserting ``13''; and

26667 (D) by adding at the end the following:

26668 ``(3) Recommendations.--

26669 ``(A) In general.--In making recommendations under

26670 paragraph (1), the advisory council shall include

26671 recommendations on--

26672 ``(i) the state of public cultivar

26673 development, including--

26674 ``(I) an analysis of existing

26675 cultivar research investments;

26676 ``(II) the research gaps relating to

26677 the development of cultivars across a

26678 diverse range of crops; and

26679 ``(III) an assessment of the state

26680 of commercialization of federally funded

26681 cultivars;

26682 ``(ii) the training and resources needed to

26683 meet future breeding challenges;

26684 ``(iii) the appropriate levels of Federal

26685 funding for cultivar development for underserved

26686 crops and geographic areas; and

26687 ``(iv) the development of the plan described

26688 in section 1632(d)(6).''; and

26689 (2) in subsection (c)--

26692 ``6''; and

26693 (ii) by inserting ``economics and policy,''

26694 after ``agricultural sciences,'';

26695 (B) in paragraph (2)--

26696 (i) by striking ``One-third'' and inserting

26697 ``3''; and

26698 (ii) by inserting ``community development,''

26699 after ``public policy,''; and

26700 (C) by adding at the end the following:

26702 individuals with expertise in public cultivar and animal breed

26703 development.

26704 ``(4) 4 of the members shall be appointed from among

26705 individuals representing--

26706 ``(A) 1862 Institutions (as defined in section 2 of

26707 the Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education

26708 Reform Act of 1998 (7 U.S.C. 7601));

26709 ``(B) 1890 Institutions (as defined in section 2 of

26710 the Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education

26711 Reform Act of 1998 (7 U.S.C. 7601));

26714 Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7 U.S.C.

26715 3103)); or

26716 ``(D) 1994 Institutions (as defined in section 532

26717 of the Equity in Educational Land-Grant Status Act of

26718 1994 (7 U.S.C. 301 note; Public Law 103-382)).''.

26726SEC. 7207. NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL WEATHER INFORMATION SYSTEM.

26731SEC. 7208. AGRICULTURAL GENOME TO PHENOME INITIATIVE.

26732

26733 Section 1671 of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act

26734of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5924) is amended--

26735 (1) in the section heading, by inserting ``to phenome''

26736 after ``genome'';

26737 (2) by striking subsection (a) and inserting the following:

26738

26739 ``(a) Goals.--The goals of this section are--

26740 ``(1) to expand knowledge concerning genomes and phenomes of

26741 crops and animals of importance to the agriculture sector of the

26742 United States;

26743 ``(2) to understand how variable weather, environments, and

26744 production systems impact the growth and productivity of

26745 specific varieties of crops and species of animals in order to

26746 provide greater accuracy in predicting crop and animal

26747 performance under variable conditions;

26748 ``(3) to support research that leverages plant and animal

26749 genomic information with phenotypic and environmental data

26750 through an interdisciplinary framework, leading to a novel

26751 understanding of plant and animal processes that affect growth,

26752 productivity, and the ability to predict performance, which will

26753 result in the deployment of superior varieties and species to

26754 producers and improved crop and animal management

26755 recommendations for farmers and ranchers;

26756 ``(4) to catalyze and coordinate research that links

26757 genomics and predictive phenomics at different sites across the

26758 United States to achieve advances in crops and animals that

26759 generate societal benefits;

26760 ``(5) to combine fields such as genetics, genomics, plant

26761 physiology, agronomy, climatology, and crop modeling with

26762 computation and informatics, statistics, and engineering;

26763 ``(6) to combine fields such as genetics, genomics, animal

26764 physiology, meat science, animal nutrition, and veterinary

26765 science with computation and informatics, statistics, and

26766 engineering;

26767 ``(7) to focus on crops and animals that will yield

26768 scientifically important results that will enhance the

26769 usefulness of many other crops and animals;

26770 ``(8) to build on genomic research, such as the Plant Genome

26771 Research Project and the National Animal Genome Research

26772 Program, to understand gene function in production environments

26773 that is expected to have considerable returns for crops and

26774 animals of importance to the agriculture of the United States;

26775 ``(9) to develop improved data analytics to enhance

26776 understanding of the biological function of genes;

26777 ``(10) to allow resources developed under this section,

26778 including data, software, germplasm, and other biological

26779 materials, to be openly accessible to all persons, subject to

26780 any confidentiality requirements imposed by law; and

26781 ``(11) to encourage international partnerships with each

26782 partner country responsible for financing its own research.'';

26783

26784[[Page 132 STAT. 4806]]

26785

26786 (3) by striking subsection (b) and inserting the following:

26787

26788 ``(b) Duties of Secretary.--The Secretary of Agriculture (referred

26789to in this section as the `Secretary') shall conduct a research

26790initiative, to be known as the `Agricultural Genome to Phenome

26791Initiative', for the purpose of--

26792 ``(1) studying agriculturally significant crops and animals

26793 in production environments to achieve sustainable and secure

26794 agricultural production;

26795 ``(2) ensuring that current gaps in existing knowledge of

26796 agricultural crop and animal genetics and phenomics are filled;

26797 ``(3) identifying and developing a functional understanding

26798 of relevant genes from animals and agronomically relevant genes

26799 from crops that are of importance to the agriculture sector of

26800 the United States;

26801 ``(4) ensuring future genetic improvement of crops and

26802 animals of importance to the agriculture sector of the United

26803 States;

26804 ``(5) studying the relevance of diverse germplasm as a

26805 source of unique genes that may be of importance in the future;

26806 ``(6) enhancing genetics to reduce the economic impact of

26807 pathogens on crops and animals of importance to the agriculture

26808 sector of the United States;

26809 ``(7) disseminating findings to relevant audiences; and

26810 ``(8) otherwise carrying out this section.'';

26811 (4) in subsection (c)(1), by inserting ``, acting through

26812 the National Institute of Food and Agriculture,'' after ``The

26813 Secretary'';

26814 (5) in subsection (e), by inserting ``to Phenome'' after

26815 ``Genome''; and

26816 (6) by adding at the end the following:

26817

26818 ``(f) Authorization of Appropriations.--There is authorized to be

26819appropriated to carry out this section $40,000,000 for each of fiscal

26820years 2019 through 2023.''.

26821SEC. 7209. HIGH-PRIORITY RESEARCH AND EXTENSION INITIATIVES.

26822

26823 Section 1672 of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act

26824of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5925) is amended--

26825 (1) in subsection (d)--

26826 (A) in paragraph (8)--

26827 (i) in the heading, by striking ``Alfalfa and

26828 forage'' and inserting ``Alfalfa seed and alfalfa

26829 forage systems'';

26830 (ii) by striking ``alfalfa and forage'' and

26831 inserting ``alfalfa seed and alfalfa forage

26832 systems''; and

26833 (iii) by striking ``alfalfa and other forages,

26834 and'' and inserting ``alfalfa seed and other

26835 alfalfa forage''; and

26836 (B) by adding at the end the following new

26837 paragraphs:

26838 ``(11) Macadamia tree health initiative.--Research and

26839 extension grants may be made under this section for the purposes

26840 of--

26841 ``(A) developing and disseminating science-based

26842 tools and treatments to combat the macadamia felted

26843 coccid (Eriococcus ironsidei); and

26844 ``(B) establishing an areawide integrated pest

26845 management program in areas affected by, or areas at

26846 risk of being affected by, the macadamia felted coccid.

26847

26848[[Page 132 STAT. 4807]]

26849

26850 ``(12) National turfgrass research initiative.--Research and

26851 extension grants may be made under this section for the purposes

26852 of--

26853 ``(A) carrying out or enhancing research related to

26854 turfgrass and sod issues;

26855 ``(B) enhancing production and uses of turfgrass for

26856 the general public;

26857 ``(C) identifying new turfgrass varieties with

26858 superior drought, heat, cold, and pest tolerance to

26859 reduce water, fertilizer, and pesticide use;

26860 ``(D) selecting genetically superior turfgrasses and

26861 developing improved technologies for managing

26862 commercial, residential, and recreational turfgrass

26863 areas;

26864 ``(E) producing turfgrasses that--

26865 ``(i) aid in mitigating soil erosion;

26866 ``(ii) protect against pollutant runoff into

26867 waterways; or

26868 ``(iii) provide other environmental benefits;

26869 ``(F) investigating, preserving, and protecting

26870 native plant species, including grasses not currently

26871 utilized in turfgrass systems;

26872 ``(G) creating systems for more economical and

26873 viable turfgrass seed and sod production throughout the

26874 United States; and

26875 ``(H) investigating the turfgrass phytobiome and

26876 developing biologic products to enhance soil, enrich

26877 plants, and mitigate pests.

26878 ``(13) Fertilizer management initiative.--

26879 ``(A) In general.--Research and extension grants may

26880 be made under this section for the purpose of carrying

26881 out research to improve fertilizer use efficiency in

26882 crops--

26883 ``(i) to maximize crop yield; and

26884 ``(ii) to minimize nutrient losses to surface

26885 and groundwater and the atmosphere.

26886 ``(B) Priority.--In awarding grants under

26887 subparagraph (A), the Secretary shall give priority to

26888 research examining the impact of the source, rate,

26889 timing, and placement of plant nutrients.

26890 ``(14) Cattle fever tick program.--Research and extension

26891 grants may be made under this section to study cattle fever

26892 ticks--

26893 ``(A) to facilitate the understanding of the role of

26894 wildlife in the persistence and spread of cattle fever

26895 ticks;

26896 ``(B) to develop advanced methods for eradication of

26897 cattle fever ticks, including--

26898 ``(i) alternative treatment methods for cattle

26899 and other susceptible species;

26900 ``(ii) field treatment for premises, including

26901 corral pens and pasture loafing areas;

26902 ``(iii) methods for treatment and control on

26903 infested wildlife;

26904 ``(iv) biological control agents; and

26905 ``(v) new and improved vaccines;

26906 ``(C) to evaluate rangeland vegetation that impacts

26907 the survival of cattle fever ticks;

26908

26909[[Page 132 STAT. 4808]]

26910

26911 ``(D) to improve management of diseases relating to

26912 cattle fever ticks that are associated with wildlife,

26913 livestock, and human health;

26914 ``(E) to improve diagnostic detection of tick-

26915 infested or infected animals and pastures; and

26916 ``(F) to conduct outreach to impacted ranchers,

26917 hunters, and landowners to integrate tactics and

26918 document sustainability of best practices.

26919 ``(15) Laying hen and turkey research program.--Research

26920 grants may be made under this section for the purpose of

26921 improving the efficiency and sustainability of laying hen and

26922 turkey production through integrated, collaborative research and

26923 technology transfer. Emphasis may be placed on laying hen and

26924 turkey disease prevention, antimicrobial resistance, nutrition,

26925 gut health, and alternative housing systems under extreme

26926 seasonal weather conditions.

26927 ``(16) Chronic wasting disease.--Research and extension

26928 grants may be made under this section for the purposes of

26929 supporting research projects at land-grant colleges and

26930 universities (as defined in section 1404 of the National

26931 Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of

26932 1977 (7 U.S.C. 3103)) with established deer research programs

26933 for the purposes of treating, mitigating, or eliminating chronic

26934 wasting disease.

26935 ``(17) Algae agriculture research program.--Research and

26936 extension grants may be made under this section for the

26937 development and testing of algae and algae systems (including

26938 micro- and macro-algae systems).

26939 ``(18) Nutrient management.--Research and extension grants

26940 may be made under this section for the purposes of examining

26941 nutrient management based on the source, rate, timing, and

26942 placement of crop nutrients.

26943 ``(19) Dryland farming agricultural systems.--Research and

26944 extension grants may be made under this section for the purposes

26945 of carrying out or enhancing research on the utilization of big

26946 data for more precise management of dryland farming agricultural

26947 systems.

26948 ``(20) Hop plant health initiative.--Research and extension

26949 grants may be made under this section for the purposes of

26950 developing and disseminating science-based tools and treatments

26951 to combat diseases of hops caused by the plant pathogens

26952 Podosphaera macularis and Pseudoperonospora humuli.'';

26953 (2) in subsection (e)(5), by striking ``2018'' and inserting

26954 ``2023'';

26955 (3) in subsection (f)(5), by striking ``2018'' and inserting

26956 ``2023'';

26957 (4) in subsection (g)--

26958 (A) in paragraphs (1)(B), (2)(B), and (3), by

26959 striking ``2018'' each place it appears and inserting

26960 ``2023'';

26961 (B) by redesignating paragraphs (4) and (5) as

26962 paragraphs (5) and (6), respectively; and

26963 (C) by inserting after paragraph (3) the following

26964 new paragraph:

26965 ``(4) Enhanced coordination of honeybee and pollinator

26966 research.--

26967 ``(A) In general.--The Chief Scientist of the

26968 Department of Agriculture shall coordinate research,

26969 extension, education, and economic activities in the

26970 Department of

26971

26972[[Page 132 STAT. 4809]]

26973

26974 Agriculture relating to native and managed pollinator

26975 health and habitat.

26976 ``(B) Duties.--In carrying out subparagraph (A), the

26977 Chief Scientist shall--

26978 ``(i) assign an individual to serve in the

26979 Office of the Chief Scientist as a Honeybee and

26980 Pollinator Research Coordinator who shall be

26981 responsible for leading the efforts of the Chief

26982 Scientist in carrying out such subparagraph;

26983 ``(ii) implement and coordinate pollinator

26984 health research efforts of the Department, as

26985 recommended by the Pollinator Health Task Force;

26986 ``(iii) establish annual strategic priorities

26987 and goals for the Department for native and

26988 managed pollinator research;

26989 ``(iv) communicate such priorities and goals

26990 to each agency or office of the Department of

26991 Agriculture, the managed pollinator industry, and

26992 relevant grant recipients under programs

26993 administered by the Secretary; and

26994 ``(v) coordinate and identify all research on

26995 native and managed pollinator health needed and

26996 conducted by the Department of Agriculture and

26997 relevant grant recipients under programs

26998 administered by the Secretary to ensure

26999 consistency and reduce unintended duplication of

27000 effort.

27001 ``(C) Research.--In coordinating research activities

27002 under subparagraph (A), the Chief Scientist shall ensure

27003 that such research--

27004 ``(i) identifies and addresses the multiple

27005 stressors on pollinator health, including pests

27006 and pathogens, reduced habitat, lack of

27007 nutritional resources, and exposure to pesticides;

27008 ``(ii) evaluates stewardship and management

27009 practices of managed pollinators that would impact

27010 managed pollinator health;

27011 ``(iii) documents the prevalence of major

27012 pests, such as varroa destructor (commonly

27013 referred to as the varroa mite), and diseases that

27014 are transported between States through practices

27015 involving managed pollinators;

27016 ``(iv) evaluates the impact of overcrowding of

27017 colonies for pollination services and the impact

27018 of such overcrowding on pollinator health status

27019 and pollinator health recovery;

27020 ``(v) evaluates and reports on the health

27021 differences of managed pollinators in--

27022 ``(I) crops not requiring contract

27023 pollination;

27024 ``(II) crops requiring contract

27025 pollination; and

27026 ``(III) native habitat;

27027 ``(vi) evaluates the impact of horticultural

27028 and agricultural pest management practices on

27029 native and managed pollinator colonies in diverse

27030 agroecosystems;

27031 ``(vii) documents pesticide residues that

27032 are--

27033 ``(I) found in native and managed

27034 pollinator colonies; and

27035

27036[[Page 132 STAT. 4810]]

27037

27038 ``(II) associated with typical

27039 localized commercial crop pest

27040 management practices;

27041 ``(viii) with respect to native and managed

27042 pollinator colonies visiting crops for crop

27043 pollination or honey production purposes,

27044 documents--

27045 ``(I) the strength and health of

27046 such colonies;

27047 ``(II) the survival, growth,

27048 reproduction, and production of such

27049 colonies;

27050 ``(III) pests, pathogens, and

27051 viruses that affect such colonies;

27052 ``(IV) environmental conditions of

27053 such colonies;

27054 ``(V) beekeeper practices; and

27055 ``(VI) any other relevant

27056 information, as determined by the Chief

27057 Scientist;

27058 ``(ix) documents, with respect to healthy

27059 populations of managed pollinators, best

27060 management practices and other practices for

27061 managed pollinators and crop managers;

27062 ``(x) evaluates the effectiveness of--

27063 ``(I) conservation practices that

27064 target the specific needs of native and

27065 managed pollinator habitats;

27066 ``(II) incentives that allow for the

27067 expansion of native and managed

27068 pollinator forage acreage; and

27069 ``(III) managed pollinator breeding

27070 practices and efforts to, with respect

27071 to managed pollinators, avoid creating a

27072 genetic bottleneck and improve genetic

27073 diversity;

27074 ``(xi) in the case of commercially managed

27075 pollinator colonies, continues to gather data--

27076 ``(I) on an annual basis with

27077 respect to losses of such colonies,

27078 splits of such colonies, and the total

27079 number of pollinator colonies;

27080 ``(II) on rising input costs; and

27081 ``(III) overall economic value to

27082 the food economy; and

27083 ``(xii) addresses any other issue relating to

27084 native and managed pollinators, as determined by

27085 the Chief Scientist, in consultation with

27086 scientific experts.

27087 ``(D) Publication.--The Chief Scientist, to the

27088 maximum extent practicable, shall--

27089 ``(i) make publicly available the results of

27090 the research described in subparagraph (C); and

27091 ``(ii) in the case of the research described

27092 in subparagraph (C)(vi), publish any data or

27093 reports that were produced by the Department of

27094 Agriculture but not made publicly available during

27095 the period beginning on January 1, 2008, and

27096 ending on the date of the enactment of the

27097 Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018.''; and

27098 (5) in subsection (h), by striking ``2018'' and inserting

27099 ``2023''.

27100

27101[[Page 132 STAT. 4811]]

27102

27110 under subsection (e),'' after ``Board,''; and

27114 health,'' after ``conservation''; and

27115 (2) in subsection (e)--

27118 at the end;

27152SEC. 7212. URBAN, INDOOR, AND OTHER EMERGING AGRICULTURAL

27153 PRODUCTION RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND

27154 EXTENSION INITIATIVE.

27155

27156 (a) In General.--The Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act

27157of 1990 is amended by inserting after section 1672D (7 U.S.C. 5925f) the

27158following:

27159

27160[[Page 132 STAT. 4812]]

27161

27162``SEC. 1672E. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 5925g.&gt;&gt; URBAN, INDOOR, AND OTHER

27163 EMERGING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION

27164 RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION

27165 INITIATIVE.

27166

27167 ``(a) Competitive Research and Extension Grants Authorized.--In

27168consultation with the Urban Agriculture and Innovative Production

27169Advisory Committee established under section 222(b) of the Department of

27170Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994, the Secretary may make

27171competitive grants to support research, education, and extension

27172activities for the purposes of facilitating the development of urban,

27173indoor, and other emerging agricultural production, harvesting,

27174transportation, aggregation, packaging, distribution, and markets,

27175including by--

27176 ``(1) assessing and developing strategies to remediate

27177 contaminated sites;

27178 ``(2) determining and developing the best production

27179 management and integrated pest management practices;

27180 ``(3) identifying and promoting the horticultural, social,

27181 and economic factors that contribute to successful urban,

27182 indoor, and other emerging agricultural production;

27183 ``(4) analyzing the means by which new agricultural sites

27184 are determined, including an evaluation of soil quality,

27185 condition of a building, or local community needs;

27186 ``(5) exploring new technologies that minimize energy,

27187 lighting systems, water, and other inputs for increased food

27188 production;

27189 ``(6) examining building material efficiencies and

27190 structural upgrades for the purpose of optimizing growth of

27191 agricultural products;

27192 ``(7) developing new crop varieties and agricultural

27193 products to connect to new markets; or

27194 ``(8) examining the impacts of crop exposure to urban

27195 elements on environmental quality and food safety.

27196

27197 ``(b) Grant Types and Process.--Subparagraphs (A) through (E) of

27198paragraph (4), paragraph (7), and paragraph (11)(B) of subsection (b) of

27199the Competitive, Special, and Facilities Research Grant Act (7 U.S.C.

272003157) shall apply with respect to the making of grants under this

27201section.

27202 ``(c) Priority.--The Secretary may give priority to grant proposals

27203that involve--

27204 ``(1) the cooperation of multiple entities; or

27205 ``(2) States or regions with a high concentration of or

27206 significant interest in urban farms, rooftop farms, and indoor

27207 production facilities.

27208

27209 ``(d) Funding.--

27210 ``(1) Mandatory funding.--Of the funds of the Commodity

27211 Credit Corporation, the Secretary shall use to carry out this

27212 section $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2019, to remain available

27213 until expended.

27214 ``(2) Authorization of appropriations.--In addition to

27215 amounts made available under paragraph (1), there is authorized

27216 to be appropriated to carry out this section $10,000,000 for

27217 each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023.''.

27218

27219 (b) Data Collection on Urban, Indoor, and Emerging Agricultural

27220Production.--

27221 (1) In general.--Not later than one year after the date of

27222 enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall conduct as a follow-

27223 on study to the census of agriculture conducted in the

27224

27225[[Page 132 STAT. 4813]]

27226

27227 calendar year 2017 under section 2 of the Census of Agriculture

27228 Act of 1997 (7 U.S.C. 2204g) a census of urban, indoor, and

27229 other emerging agricultural production, including information

27230 about--

27231 (A) community gardens and farms located in urban

27232 areas, suburbs, and urban clusters;

27233 (B) rooftop farms, outdoor vertical production, and

27234 green walls;

27235 (C) indoor farms, greenhouses, and high-tech

27236 vertical technology farms;

27237 (D) hydroponic, aeroponic, and aquaponic farm

27238 facilities; and

27239 (E) other innovations in agricultural production, as

27240 determined by the Secretary.

27241 (2) Authorization of appropriations.--There is authorized to

27242 be appropriated to carry out this subsection $14,000,000 for the

27243 period of fiscal years 2019 through 2021.

27244SEC. 7213. CENTERS OF EXCELLENCE AT 1890 INSTITUTIONS.

27245

27246 Section 1673 of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act

27247of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5926) is amended by adding at the end the following:

27248 ``(d) Centers of Excellence at 1890s Institutions.--

27249 ``(1) Recognition.--The Secretary shall recognize not less

27250 than 3 centers of excellence, each led by an 1890 Institution

27251 (as defined in section 2 of the Agricultural Research,

27252 Extension, and Education Reform Act of 1998 (7 U.S.C. 7601)), to

27253 focus on 1 or more of the areas described in paragraph (2).

27254 ``(2) Areas of focus.--

27255 ``(A) Student success and workforce development.--A

27256 center of excellence established under paragraph (1) may

27257 engage in activities to ensure that students have the

27258 skills and education needed to work in agriculture and

27259 food industries, agriculture science, technology,

27260 engineering, mathematics, and related fields of study.

27261 ``(B) Nutrition, health, wellness, and quality of

27262 life.--A center of excellence established under

27263 paragraph (1) may carry out research, education, and

27264 extension programs that increase access to healthy food,

27265 improve nutrition, mitigate preventive disease, and

27266 develop strategies to assist limited resource

27267 individuals in accessing health and nutrition resources.

27268 ``(C) Farming systems, rural prosperity, and

27269 economic sustainability.--A center of excellence

27270 established under paragraph (1) may share best practices

27271 with farmers to improve agricultural production,

27272 processing, and marketing, reduce urban food deserts,

27273 examine new uses for traditional and nontraditional

27274 crops, animals, and natural resources, and continue

27275 activities carried out by the Center for Innovative and

27276 Sustainable Small Farms, Ranches, and Forest Lands.

27277 ``(D) Global food security and defense.--A center of

27278 excellence established under paragraph (1) may engage in

27279 international partnerships that strengthen agricultural

27280 development in developing countries, partner with

27281 international researchers regarding new and emerging

27282 animal

27283

27284[[Page 132 STAT. 4814]]

27285

27286 and plant pests and diseases, engage in agricultural

27287 disaster recovery, and continue activities carried out

27288 by the Center for International Engagement.

27289 ``(E) Natural resources, energy, and environment.--A

27290 center of excellence established under paragraph (1) may

27291 focus on protecting and managing domestic natural

27292 resources for current and future production of food and

27293 agricultural products.

27294 ``(F) Emerging technologies.--A center of excellence

27295 established under paragraph (1) may focus on the

27296 development of emerging technologies to increase

27297 agricultural productivity, enhance small farm economic

27298 viability, and improve rural communities by developing

27299 genetic and sensor technologies for food and agriculture

27300 and providing technology training to farmers.

27301 ``(3) Authorization of appropriations.--There is authorized

27302 to be appropriated to carry out this subsection $10,000,000 for

27303 each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023.

27304 ``(4) Report.--Not later than 1 year after the date of

27305 enactment of the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018, and every

27306 year thereafter, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on

27307 Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the Committee on

27308 Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report

27309 describing--

27310 ``(A) the resources invested in the centers of

27311 excellence established under paragraph (1); and

27312 ``(B) the work being done by those centers of

27313 excellence.''.

27326 occupations; or

27327 ``(B) are pursuing new farming opportunities.'';

27404

27405[[Page 132 STAT. 4816]]

27406

27407 ``(B) size-controlling rootstock systems for

27408 perennial crops;'';

27410 specialty crop pollinators;'' and inserting the following:

27411 ``including--

27412 ``(A) threats to specialty crop pollinators;

27415 of existing natural enemy complexes;'';

27418 the following: ``efforts--

27419 ``(A) to improve'';

27433 intensive tasks in production and processing;

27435 ``(C) decision support systems driven by phenology

27436 and environmental factors;

27437 ``(D) improved monitoring systems for agricultural

27438 pests; and

27439 ``(E) effective systems for preharvest and

27440 postharvest management of quarantine pests; and''.

27441

27443Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act of 1998 (7

27466 Subtitle D--Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008

27467

27468 PART I--AGRICULTURAL SECURITY

27469

27470SEC. 7401. AGRICULTURAL BIOSECURITY COMMUNICATION CENTER.

27471

27472 Section 14112(c)(2) of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of

274732008 (7 U.S.C. 8912(c)(2)) is amended by striking ``2018'' and inserting

27474``2023''.

27504SEC. 7412. FARM AND RANCH STRESS ASSISTANCE NETWORK.

27505

27506 Section 7522 of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (7

27507U.S.C. 5936) is amended--

27508 (1) in subsection (a), by striking ``to support cooperative

27509 programs between State cooperative extension services and

27510 nonprofit organizations'' and inserting ``to eligible entities

27511 described in subsection (c)'';

27512 (2) in subsection (b)--

27513 (A) by striking paragraph (5);

27514 (B) by redesignating paragraphs (1) through (4) as

27515 subparagraphs (A) through (D), respectively, and

27516 indenting the subparagraphs appropriately;

27517 (C) by striking subparagraph (B) (as so

27518 redesignated) and inserting the following:

27519 ``(B) training, including training programs and

27520 workshops, for--

27521 ``(i) advocates for individuals who are

27522 engaged in farming, ranching, and other

27523 occupations relating to agriculture; and

27524

27525[[Page 132 STAT. 4818]]

27526

27527 ``(ii) other individuals and entities that may

27528 assist individuals who--

27529 ``(I) are engaged in farming,

27530 ranching, and other occupations relating

27531 to agriculture; and

27532 ``(II) are in crisis;'';

27533 (D) in subparagraph (C) (as so redesignated), by

27534 adding ``and'' after the semicolon at the end;

27535 (E) in subparagraph (D) (as so redesignated), by

27536 striking ``activities; and'' and inserting ``activities,

27537 including the dissemination of information and

27538 materials; or'';

27539 (F) in the matter preceding subparagraph (A) (as so

27540 redesignated), by striking ``be used to initiate'' and

27541 inserting the following: ``be used--

27542 ``(1) to initiate''; and

27543 (G) by adding at the end the following:

27544 ``(2) to enter into contracts, on a multiyear basis, with

27545 community-based, direct-service organizations to initiate,

27546 expand, or sustain programs described in paragraph (1) and

27547 subsection (a).''; and

27548 (3) by striking subsections (c) and (d) and inserting the

27549 following:

27550

27551 ``(c) Eligible Recipients.--The Secretary may award a grant under

27552this section to--

27553 ``(1) an Indian tribe (as defined in section 4 of the Indian

27554 Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C.

27555 5304));

27556 ``(2) a State department of agriculture;

27557 ``(3) a State cooperative extension service;

27558 ``(4) a qualified nonprofit organization, as determined by

27559 the Secretary;

27560 ``(5) an entity providing appropriate services, as

27561 determined by the Secretary, in 1 or more States; or

27562 ``(6) a partnership carried out by 2 or more entities

27563 described in paragraphs (1) through (5).

27564

27565 ``(d) Authorization of Appropriations.--There is authorized to be

27566appropriated to the Secretary to carry out this section $10,000,000 for

27567each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023.

27568 ``(e) Report to Congress.--

27569 ``(1) In general.--Not later than 1 year after the date of

27570 enactment of this subsection, the Secretary, in coordination

27571 with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall submit to

27572 Congress and any other relevant Federal department or agency,

27573 and make publicly available, a report describing the state of

27574 behavioral and mental health of individuals who are engaged in

27575 farming, ranching, and other occupations relating to

27576 agriculture.

27577 ``(2) Contents.--The report under paragraph (1) shall

27578 include--

27579 ``(A) an inventory and assessment of efforts to

27580 support the behavioral and mental health of individuals

27581 who are engaged in farming, ranching, and other

27582 occupations relating to agriculture by--

27583 ``(i) the Federal Government, States, and

27584 units of local government;

27585 ``(ii) communities comprised of those

27586 individuals;

27587 ``(iii) health care providers;

27588 ``(iv) State cooperative extension services;

27589 and

27590

27591[[Page 132 STAT. 4819]]

27592

27593 ``(v) other appropriate entities, as

27594 determined by the Secretary;

27595 ``(B) a description of the challenges faced by

27596 individuals who are engaged in farming, ranching, and

27597 other occupations relating to agriculture that may

27598 impact the behavioral and mental health of farmers and

27599 ranchers;

27600 ``(C) a description of how the Department of

27601 Agriculture can improve coordination and cooperation

27602 with Federal health departments and agencies, including

27603 the Department of Health and Human Services, the

27604 Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services

27605 Administration, the Health Resources and Services

27606 Administration, the Centers for Disease Control and

27607 Prevention, and the National Institutes of Health, to

27608 best address the behavioral and mental health of

27609 individuals who are engaged in farming, ranching, and

27610 other occupations relating to agriculture;

27611 ``(D) a long-term strategy for responding to the

27612 challenges described under subparagraph (B) and

27613 recommendations based on best practices for further

27614 action to be carried out by appropriate Federal

27615 departments or agencies to improve Federal Government

27616 response and seek to prevent suicide among individuals

27617 who are engaged in farming, ranching, and other

27618 occupations relating to agriculture; and

27619 ``(E) an evaluation of the impact that behavioral

27620 and mental health challenges and outcomes (including

27621 suicide) among individuals who are engaged in farming,

27622 ranching, and other agriculture related occupations have

27623 on--

27624 ``(i) the agricultural workforce;

27625 ``(ii) agricultural production;

27626 ``(iii) rural families and communities; and

27627 ``(iv) succession planning.

27628

27629 ``(f) State Defined.--For purposes of this section, the term `State'

27630has the meaning given such term in section 1404 of the National

27631Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 (7

27632U.S.C. 3103).''.

27657

27660 Land-Grant Status Act of 1994 (7 U.S.C. 301 note; Public Law

27661 103-382) is amended to read as follows:

27662``SEC. 532. DEFINITION OF 1994 INSTITUTION.

27663

27664 ``In this part, the term `1994 Institution' means any of the

27665following colleges:

27666 ``(1) Aaniiih Nakoda College.

27667 ``(2) Bay Mills Community College.

27668 ``(3) Blackfeet Community College.

27669 ``(4) Cankdeska Cikana Community College.

27670 ``(5) Chief Dull Knife College.

27671 ``(6) College of Menominee Nation.

27672 ``(7) College of the Muscogee Nation.

27673 ``(8) D-Q University.

27674 ``(9) Dine College.

27675 ``(10) Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College.

27676 ``(11) Fort Peck Community College.

27677 ``(12) Haskell Indian Nations University.

27678 ``(13) Ilisagvik College.

27679 ``(14) Institute of American Indian and Alaska Native

27680 Culture and Arts Development.

27681 ``(15) Keweenaw Bay Ojibwa Community College.

27682 ``(16) Lac Courte Oreilles Ojibwa Community College.

27683 ``(17) Leech Lake Tribal College.

27684 ``(18) Little Big Horn College.

27685 ``(19) Little Priest Tribal College.

27686 ``(20) Navajo Technical University.

27687 ``(21) Nebraska Indian Community College.

27688 ``(22) Northwest Indian College.

27689 ``(23) Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College.

27690 ``(24) Oglala Lakota College.

27691 ``(25) Red Lake Nation College.

27692 ``(26) Saginaw Chippewa Tribal College.

27693 ``(27) Salish Kootenai College.

27694 ``(28) Sinte Gleska University.

27695 ``(29) Sisseton Wahpeton College.

27696 ``(30) Sitting Bull College.

27697 ``(31) Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute.

27698 ``(32) Stone Child College.

27699 ``(33) Tohono O'odham Community College.

27700 ``(34) Turtle Mountain Community College.

27701 ``(35) United Tribes Technical College.

27702 ``(36) White Earth Tribal and Community College.''.

27703 (2) &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 301 note.&gt;&gt; Effective date.--The

27704 amendment made by paragraph (1) shall take effect on the date of

27705 the enactment of this Act.

27706

27707 (b) Endowment for 1994 Institutions.--Section 533(b) of the Equity

27708in Educational Land-Grant Status Act of 1994 (7 U.S.C. 301 note; Public

27709Law 103-382) is amended in the first sentence by striking ``2018'' and

27710inserting ``2023''.

27712Equity in Educational Land-Grant Status Act of 1994 (7 U.S.C. 301 note;

27723SEC. 7503. RESEARCH FACILITIES ACT.

27724

27725 (a) Agricultural Research Facility Defined.--The Research Facilities

27726Act is amended--

27727 (1) in section 2(1) (7 U.S.C. 390(1)) by striking ``a

27728 college, university, or nonprofit institution'' and inserting

27729 ``an entity eligible to receive funds under a capacity and

27730 infrastructure program (as defined in section 251(f)(1)(C) of

27731 the Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994 (7

27732 U.S.C. 6971(f)(1)(C)))''; and

27733 (2) in section 3(c)(2)(D) (7 U.S.C. 390a(c)(2)(D)), by

27734 striking ``recipient college, university, or nonprofit

27735 institution'' and inserting ``recipient entity''.

27736

27737 (b) Long-term Support.--Section 3(c)(2)(D) of the Research

27738Facilities Act (7 U.S.C. 390a(c)(2)(D)), as amended by subsection (a),

27739is further amended by striking ``operating costs'' and inserting

27740``operating and maintenance costs''.

27741 (c) Competitive Grant Program.--The Research Facilities Act is

27742amended by inserting after section 3 (7 U.S.C. 390a) the following new

27743section:

27744``SEC. 4. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 390b.&gt;&gt; COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM.

27745

27746 ``The Secretary shall establish a program to make competitive grants

27747to assist in the construction, alteration, acquisition, modernization,

27748renovation, or remodeling of agricultural research facilities.''.

27749 (d) Authorization of Appropriations and Funding Limitations.--

27750Section 6 of the Research Facilities Act (7 U.S.C. 390d) is amended--

27751 (1) in subsection (a)--

27752 (A) by striking ``subsection (b),'' and inserting

27753 ``subsections (b), (c), and (d),'';

27754 (B) by striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''; and

27755 (C) by adding at the end the following new sentence:

27756 ``Funds appropriated pursuant to the preceding sentence

27757 shall be available until expended.''; and

27758 (2) by adding at the end the following new subsections:

27759

27760 ``(c) Maximum Amount.--Not more than 25 percent of the funds made

27761available pursuant to subsection (a) for any fiscal year shall be used

27762for any single agricultural research facility project.

27763 ``(d) Project Limitation.--An entity eligible to receive funds under

27764this Act may receive funds for only one project at a time.''.
