37914of 1994 (7 U.S.C. 7014(b)) is amended by adding at the end the

37915following:

37916 ``(9) The authority of the Secretary to carry out the

37917 amendments made to this title by section 772 of the Agriculture,

37918 Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related

37919 Agencies Appropriations Act, 2018.

37920 ``(10) The authority of the Secretary to carry out the

37921 amendments made to this title by the Agriculture Improvement Act

37922 of 2018.''.

37923

37924 Subtitle E--Other Miscellaneous Provisions

37925

37926 PART I--MISCELLANEOUS AGRICULTURE PROVISIONS

37927

37928SEC. 12501. ACER ACCESS AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM.

37929

37930 Section 12306(f) of the Agricultural Act of 2014 (7 U.S.C. 1632c(f))

37931is amended by striking ``2018'' and inserting ``2023''.

37932SEC. 12502. PROTECTING ANIMALS WITH SHELTER.

37933

37934 (a) Crimes Related to Domestic Violence and Stalking Targeting

37935Pets.--

37936 (1) Interstate stalking.--Section 2261A of title 18, United

37937 States Code, is amended--

37938 (A) in paragraph (1)(A)--

37939 (i) in clause (ii), by striking ``or'' at the

37940 end; and

37941 (ii) by inserting after clause (iii) the

37942 following:

37943 ``(iv) the pet, service animal, emotional

37944 support animal, or horse of that person; or''; and

37945 (B) in paragraph (2)(A)--

37946 (i) by inserting after ``to a person'' the

37947 following: ``, a pet, a service animal, an

37948 emotional support animal, or a horse''; and

37949 (ii) by striking ``or (iii)'' and inserting

37950 ``(iii), or (iv)''.

37951 (2) Interstate violation of protection order.--Section 2262

37952 of title 18, United States Code, is amended--

37953 (A) in subsection (a)--

37954 (i) in paragraph (1), by inserting after

37955 ``another person'' the following: ``or the pet,

37956 service animal, emotional support animal, or horse

37957 of that person''; and

37958 (ii) in paragraph (2), by inserting after

37959 ``proximity to, another person'' the following

37960 ``or the pet, service animal, emotional support

37961 animal, or horse of that person''; and

37962 (B) in subsection (b)(5), by inserting after ``in

37963 any other case,'' the following: ``including any case in

37964 which the offense is committed against a pet, service

37965 animal, emotional support animal, or horse,''.

37966

37967[[Page 132 STAT. 4983]]

37968

37969 (3) Restitution to include veterinary services.--Section

37970 2264 of title 18, United States Code, is amended in subsection

37971 (b)(3)--

37972 (A) by redesignating subparagraph (F) as

37973 subparagraph (G);

37974 (B) in subparagraph (E), by striking ``and'' at the

37975 end; and

37976 (C) by inserting after subparagraph (E) the

37977 following:

37978 ``(F) veterinary services relating to physical care

37979 for the victim's pet, service animal, emotional support

37980 animal, or horse; and''.

37981 (4) Definitions.--Section 2266 of title 18, United States

37982 Code, is amended by inserting after paragraph (10) the

37983 following:

37984 ``(11) Pet.--The term `pet' means a domesticated animal,

37985 such as a dog, cat, bird, rodent, fish, turtle, or other animal

37986 that is kept for pleasure rather than for commercial purposes.

37987 ``(12) Emotional support animal.--The term `emotional

37988 support animal' means an animal that is covered by the exclusion

37989 specified in section 5.303 of title 24, Code of Federal

37990 Regulations (or a successor regulation), and that is not a

37991 service animal.

37992 ``(13) Service animal.--The term `service animal' has the

37993 meaning given the term in section 36.104 of title 28, Code of

37994 Federal Regulations (or a successor regulation).''.

37995

37996 (b) &lt;&lt;NOTE: 34 USC 20127.&gt;&gt; Emergency and Transitional Pet Shelter

37997and Housing Assistance Grant Program.--

37998 (1) Grant program.--

37999 (A) In general.--The Secretary, acting in

38000 consultation with the Office of the Violence Against

38001 Women of the Department of Justice, the Secretary of

38002 Housing and Urban Development, and the Secretary of

38003 Health and Human Services, shall award grants under this

38004 subsection to eligible entities to carry out programs to

38005 provide the assistance described in paragraph (3) with

38006 respect to victims of domestic violence, dating

38007 violence, sexual assault, or stalking and the pets,

38008 service animals, emotional support animals, or horses of

38009 such victims.

38010 (B) Memorandum of understanding.--The Secretary may

38011 enter into a memorandum of understanding with the head

38012 of another Department or agency, as appropriate, to

38013 carry out any of the authorities provided to the

38014 Secretary under this section.

38015 (2) Application.--

38016 (A) In general.--An eligible entity seeking a grant

38017 under this subsection shall submit an application to the

38018 Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing

38019 such information as the Secretary may reasonably

38020 require, including--

38021 (i) a description of the activities for which

38022 a grant under this subsection is sought;

38023 (ii) such assurances as the Secretary

38024 determines to be necessary to ensure compliance by

38025 the entity with the requirements of this

38026 subsection; and

38027 (iii) a certification that the entity, before

38028 engaging with any individual domestic violence

38029 victim, will disclose to the victim any mandatory

38030 duty of the entity

38031

38032[[Page 132 STAT. 4984]]

38033

38034 to report instances of abuse and neglect

38035 (including instances of abuse and neglect of pets,

38036 service animals, emotional support animals, or

38037 horses).

38038 (B) Additional requirements.--In addition to the

38039 requirements of subparagraph (A), each application

38040 submitted by an eligible entity under that subparagraph

38041 shall--

38042 (i) not include proposals for any activities

38043 that may compromise the safety of a domestic

38044 violence victim, including--

38045 (I) background checks of domestic

38046 violence victims; or

38047 (II) clinical evaluations to

38048 determine the eligibility of such a

38049 victim for support services;

38050 (ii) not include proposals that would require

38051 mandatory services for victims or that a victim

38052 obtain a protective order in order to receive

38053 proposed services; and

38054 (iii) reflect the eligible entity's

38055 understanding of the dynamics of domestic

38056 violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or

38057 stalking.

38058 (C) Rules of construction.--Nothing in this

38059 paragraph shall be construed to require--

38060 (i) domestic violence victims to participate

38061 in the criminal justice system in order to receive

38062 services; or

38063 (ii) eligible entities receiving a grant under

38064 this subsection to breach client confidentiality.

38065 (3) Use of funds.--Grants awarded under this subsection may

38066 only be used for programs that provide--

38067 (A) emergency and transitional shelter and housing

38068 assistance for domestic violence victims with pets,

38069 service animals, emotional support animals, or horses,

38070 including assistance with respect to any construction or

38071 operating expenses of newly developed or existing

38072 emergency and transitional pet, service animal,

38073 emotional support animal, or horse shelter and housing

38074 (regardless of whether such shelter and housing is co-

38075 located at a victim service provider or within the

38076 community);

38077 (B) short-term shelter and housing assistance for

38078 domestic violence victims with pets, service animals,

38079 emotional support animals, or horses, including

38080 assistance with respect to expenses incurred for the

38081 temporary shelter, housing, boarding, or fostering of

38082 the pets, service animals, emotional support animals, or

38083 horses of domestic violence victims and other expenses

38084 that are incidental to securing the safety of such a

38085 pet, service animal, emotional support animal, or horse

38086 during the sheltering, housing, or relocation of such

38087 victims;

38088 (C) support services designed to enable a domestic

38089 violence victim who is fleeing a situation of domestic

38090 violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking

38091 to--

38092 (i) locate and secure--

38093 (I) safe housing with the victim's

38094 pet, service animal, emotional support

38095 animal, or horse; or

38096

38097[[Page 132 STAT. 4985]]

38098

38099 (II) safe accommodations for the

38100 victim's pet, service animal, emotional

38101 support animal, or horse; or

38102 (ii) provide the victim with pet, service

38103 animal, emotional support animal, or horse related

38104 services, such as transportation, care services,

38105 and other assistance; or

38106 (D) for the training of relevant stakeholders on--

38107 (i) the link between domestic violence, dating

38108 violence, sexual assault, or stalking and the

38109 abuse and neglect of pets, service animals,

38110 emotional support animals, and horses;

38111 (ii) the needs of domestic violence victims;

38112 (iii) best practices for providing support

38113 services to such victims;

38114 (iv) best practices for providing such victims

38115 with referrals to victims' services; and

38116 (v) the importance of confidentiality.

38117 (4) Grant conditions.--An eligible entity that receives a

38118 grant under this subsection shall, as a condition of such

38119 receipt, agree--

38120 (A) to be bound by the nondisclosure of confidential

38121 information requirements of section 40002(b)(2) of the

38122 Violence Against Women Act of 1994 (34 U.S.C.

38123 12291(b)(2)); and

38124 (B) that the entity shall not condition the receipt

38125 of support, housing, or other benefits provided pursuant

38126 to this subsection on the participation of domestic

38127 violence victims in any or all of the support services

38128 offered to such victims through a program carried out by

38129 the entity using grant funds.

38130 (5) Duration of assistance provided to victims.--

38131 (A) In general.--Subject to subparagraph (B),

38132 assistance provided with respect to a pet, service

38133 animal, emotional support animal, or horse of a domestic

38134 violence victim using grant funds awarded under this

38135 subsection shall be provided for a period of not more

38136 than 24 months.

38137 (B) Extension.--An eligible entity that receives a

38138 grant under this subsection may extend the 24-month

38139 period referred to in subparagraph (A) for a period of

38140 not more than 6 months in the case of a domestic

38141 violence victim who--

38142 (i) has made a good faith effort to acquire

38143 permanent housing for the victim and the victim's

38144 pet, service animal, emotional support animal, or

38145 horse during that 24-month period; and

38146 (ii) has been unable to acquire such permanent

38147 housing within that period.

38148 (6) Report to the secretary.--Not later than 1 year after

38149 the date on which an eligible entity receives a grant under this

38150 subsection and each year thereafter in which the grant funds are

38151 used, the entity shall submit to the Secretary a report that

38152 contains, with respect to assistance provided by the entity to

38153 domestic violence victims with pets, service animals, emotional

38154 support animals, or horses using grant funds received under this

38155 subsection, information on--

38156

38157[[Page 132 STAT. 4986]]

38158

38159 (A) the number of domestic violence victims with

38160 pets, service animals, emotional support animals, or

38161 horses provided such assistance; and

38162 (B) the purpose, amount, type of, and duration of

38163 such assistance.

38164 (7) Report to congress.--

38165 (A) Reporting requirement.--Not later than November

38166 1 of each even-numbered fiscal year, the Secretary shall

38167 submit to the Committee on Agriculture of the House of

38168 Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture,

38169 Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report that

38170 contains a compilation of the information contained in

38171 the reports submitted under paragraph (6).

38172 (B) Availability of report.--The Secretary shall

38173 transmit a copy of the report submitted under

38174 subparagraph (A) to--

38175 (i) the Office on Violence Against Women of

38176 the Department of Justice;

38177 (ii) the Office of Community Planning and

38178 Development of the Department of Housing and Urban

38179 Development; and

38180 (iii) the Administration for Children and

38181 Families of the Department of Health and Human

38182 Services.

38183 (8) Authorization of appropriations.--

38184 (A) In general.--There is authorized to be

38185 appropriated to carry out this subsection $3,000,000 for

38186 each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023.

38187 (B) Limitation.--Of the amount made available under

38188 subparagraph (A) in any fiscal year, not more than 5

38189 percent may be used for evaluation, monitoring,

38190 salaries, and administrative expenses.

38191 (9) Definitions.--In this subsection:

38192 (A) Domestic violence victim defined.--The term

38193 ``domestic violence victim'' means a victim of domestic

38194 violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking.

38195 (B) Eligible entity.--The term ``eligible entity''

38196 means--

38197 (i) a State;

38198 (ii) a unit of local government;

38199 (iii) an Indian tribe; or

38200 (iv) any other organization that has a

38201 documented history of effective work concerning

38202 domestic violence, dating violence, sexual

38203 assault, or stalking (as determined by the

38204 Secretary), including--

38205 (I) a domestic violence and sexual

38206 assault victim service provider;

38207 (II) a domestic violence and sexual

38208 assault coalition;

38209 (III) a community-based and

38210 culturally specific organization;

38211 (IV) any other nonprofit,

38212 nongovernmental organization; and

38213 (V) any organization that works

38214 directly with pets, service animals,

38215 emotional support animals, or horses and

38216 collaborates with any organization

38217 referred to in clauses (i) through (iv),

38218 including--

38219 (aa) an animal shelter; and

38220

38221[[Page 132 STAT. 4987]]

38222

38223 (bb) an animal welfare

38224 organization.

38225 (C) Emotional support animal.--The term ``emotional

38226 support animal'' means an animal that is covered by the

38227 exclusion specified in section 5.303 of title 24, Code

38228 of Federal Regulations (or a successor regulation), and

38229 that is not a service animal.

38230 (D) Pet.--The term ``pet'' means a domesticated

38231 animal, such as a dog, cat, bird, rodent, fish, turtle,

38232 or other animal that is kept for pleasure rather than

38233 for commercial purposes.

38234 (E) Service animal.--The term ``service animal'' has

38235 the meaning given the term in section 36.104 of title

38236 28, Code of Federal Regulations (or a successor

38237 regulation).

38238 (F) Other terms.--Except as otherwise provided in

38239 this subsection, terms used in this section shall have

38240 the meaning given such terms in section 40002(a) of the

38241 Violence Against Women Act of 1994 (34 U.S.C. 12291(a)).

38242

38243 (c) Sense of Congress.--It is the sense of Congress that States

38244should encourage the inclusion of protections against violent or

38245threatening acts against the pet, service animal, emotional support

38246animal, or horse of a person in domestic violence protection orders.

38247SEC. 12503. MARKETING ORDERS.

38248

38249 Section 8e(a) of the Agricultural Adjustment Act (7 U.S.C. 608e-

382501(a)), reenacted with amendments by the Agricultural Marketing Agreement

38251Act of 1937, is amended by inserting ``cherries, pecans,'' after

38252``walnuts,''.

38253SEC. 12504. ESTABLISHMENT OF FOOD LOSS AND WASTE REDUCTION

38254 LIAISON.

38255

38256 Subtitle A of the Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of

382571994 (7 U.S.C. 6901 et seq.), as amended by sections 12202, 12302, and

3825812403, is further amended by adding at the end the following:

38259``SEC. 224. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 6924.&gt;&gt; FOOD LOSS AND WASTE REDUCTION

38260 LIAISON.

38261

38262 ``(a) Establishment.--The Secretary shall establish a Food Loss and

38263Waste Reduction Liaison to coordinate Federal, State, local, and

38264nongovernmental programs, and other efforts, to measure and reduce the

38265incidence of food loss and waste in accordance with this section.

38266 ``(b) In General.--The Food Loss and Waste Reduction Liaison shall--

38267 ``(1) coordinate food loss and waste reduction efforts

38268 within the Department of Agriculture and with other Federal

38269 agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency and the

38270 Food and Drug Administration;

38271 ``(2) support and promote Federal programs to measure and

38272 reduce the incidence of food loss and waste and increase food

38273 recovery;

38274 ``(3) provide information to, and serve as a resource for,

38275 entities engaged in food loss and waste reduction and food

38276 recovery, including information about the availability of, and

38277 eligibility requirements for, participation in Federal, State,

38278 local, and nongovernmental programs;

38279 ``(4) raise awareness of the liability protections afforded

38280 under the Bill Emerson Good Samaritan Food Donation Act

38281

38282[[Page 132 STAT. 4988]]

38283

38284 (42 U.S.C. 1791) to persons engaged in food loss and waste

38285 reduction and food recovery; and

38286 ``(5) make recommendations with respect to expanding

38287 innovative food recovery models and reducing the incidence of

38288 food loss and waste.

38289

38290 ``(c) Cooperative Agreements.--For purposes of carrying out the

38291duties under subsection (b), the Food Loss and Waste Reduction Liaison

38292may enter into contracts or cooperative agreements with the research

38293centers of the Research, Education, and Economics mission area,

38294institutions of higher education (as defined in section 101 of the

38295Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001)), or nonprofit

38296organizations for--

38297 ``(1) the development of educational materials;

38298 ``(2) the conduct of workshops and courses; or

38299 ``(3) the conduct of research on best practices with respect

38300 to food loss and waste reduction and food recovery.

38301

38302 ``(d) Study on Food Waste.--The Secretary shall conduct a study, in

38303consultation with the Food Loss and Waste Reduction Liaison, to evaluate

38304and determine--

38305 ``(1) methods of measuring food waste;

38306 ``(2) standards for the volume of food waste;

38307 ``(3) factors that contribute to food waste;

38308 ``(4) the cost and volume of food loss;

38309 ``(5) the effectiveness of existing liability protections

38310 afforded under the Bill Emerson Good Samaritan Food Donation Act

38311 (42 U.S.C. 1791); and

38312 ``(6) measures to ensure that programs contemplated,

38313 undertaken, or funded by the Department of Agriculture do not

38314 disrupt existing food waste recovery and disposal efforts by

38315 commercial, marketing, or business relationships.

38316

38317 ``(e) Reports.--

38318 ``(1) Initial report.--Not later than 1 year after the date

38319 of enactment of this section, the Food Loss and Waste Liaison

38320 shall submit to the Committee on Agriculture of the House of

38321 Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and

38322 Forestry of the Senate a report that describes the results of

38323 the study conducted under subsection (d).

38324 ``(2) Report.--Not later than 1 year after the date of the

38325 submission of the report under paragraph (1), the Secretary

38326 shall submit to the Committee on Agriculture of the House of

38327 Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and

38328 Forestry of the Senate a report that contains, with respect to

38329 the preceding year--

38330 ``(A) an estimate of the quantity of food waste

38331 during such year; and

38332 ``(B) the results of the food waste reduction and

38333 loss prevention activities carried out or led by the

38334 Department of Agriculture.''.

38335SEC. 12505. REPORT ON BUSINESS CENTERS.

38336

38337 (a) In General.--Not later than 365 days after the date of enactment

38338of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall submit

38339to the Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the

38340Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report

38341evaluating each business center established in the Department of

38342Agriculture.

38343

38344[[Page 132 STAT. 4989]]

38345

38346 (b) Inclusions.--The report under subsection (a) shall include--

38347 (1) an examination of the effectiveness of each business

38348 center in carrying out its mission, including any

38349 recommendations to improve the operation of and function of any

38350 of those business centers; and

38351 (2) an evaluation of--

38352 (A) the impact the business centers have on customer

38353 service of the Department of Agriculture;

38354 (B) the impact on the annual budget for agencies the

38355 budget offices of which have been relocated to the

38356 business center, and the effectiveness of funds used to

38357 support the business centers, including an accounting of

38358 all discretionary and mandatory funding provided to the

38359 business center for conservation and farm services

38360 from--

38361 (i) the Natural Resources Conservation

38362 Service;

38363 (ii) the Farm Service Agency; and

38364 (iii) the Risk Management Agency;

38365 (C) funding described in subparagraph (B) spent on

38366 information technology modernizations;

38367 (D) the impact that the business centers have had on

38368 the human resources of the Department of Agriculture,

38369 including hiring;

38370 (E) any concerns or problems with the business

38371 centers; and

38372 (F) any positive or negative impact that the

38373 business centers have had on the functionality of the

38374 Department of Agriculture.

38375SEC. 12506. REPORT ON PERSONNEL.

38376

38377 For the period of fiscal years 2019 through 2023, the Secretary

38378shall submit to the Committee on Agriculture of the House of

38379Representatives and the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and

38380Forestry of the Senate a biannual report describing the number of staff

38381years and employees of each agency of the Department of Agriculture.

38382SEC. 12507. REPORT ON ABSENT LANDLORDS.

38383

38384 (a) In General.--Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment

38385of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report describing

38386the effects of absent landlords on the long-term economic health of

38387agricultural production, including the effect of absent landlords on--

38388 (1) land valuation;

38389 (2) soil health; and

38390 (3) the economic stability of rural communities.

38391

38392 (b) Contents.--The report under subsection (a) shall include--

38393 (1) a description of the positive and negative effects of an

38394 absent landlord on the land owned by the landlord, including--

38395 (A) the effect of an absent landlord on the long-

38396 term value of the land; and

38397 (B) the environmental and economic impact of an

38398 absent landlord on the surrounding community; and

38399 (2) recommendations to policymakers concerning how to

38400 mitigate those effects when necessary.

38401

38402[[Page 132 STAT. 4990]]

38403

38404SEC. 12508. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 2266a.&gt;&gt; CENTURY FARMS PROGRAM.

38405

38406 The Secretary shall establish a program under which the Secretary

38407recognizes any farm that--

38408 (1) a State department of agriculture or similar statewide

38409 agricultural organization recognizes as a Century Farm; or

38410 (2)(A) is defined as a farm or ranch under section 4284.902

38411 of title 7, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the

38412 date of enactment of this Act);

38413 (B) has been in continuous operation for at least 100 years;

38414 and

38415 (C) has been owned by the same family for at least 100

38416 consecutive years, as verified through deeds, wills, abstracts,

38417 tax statements, or other similar legal documents considered

38418 appropriate by the Secretary.

38419SEC. 12509. REPORT ON IMPORTATION OF LIVE DOGS.

38420

38421 (a) In General.--Not later than 1 year after the date of the

38422enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on

38423Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the Committee on

38424Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report on the

38425importation of live dogs into the United States.

38426 (b) Contents.--The report submitted under subsection (a) shall

38427include, with respect to the importation of live dogs into the United

38428States for each of the 3 most recent calendar years for which data are

38429available--

38430 (1) the total number of live dogs imported;

38431 (2) the number of live dogs imported as personal pets;

38432 (3) the number of live dogs imported for resale (as defined

38433 in section 18(a) of the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. 2148(a));

38434 (4) the number of live dogs for which importation was

38435 requested but denied due to the proposed importation failing to

38436 meet the requirements under--

38437 (A) section 18 of the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C.

38438 2148);

38439 (B) section 71.51 of title 42, Code of Federal

38440 Regulations (or any successor regulations); or

38441 (C) any other Federal law; and

38442 (5) any recommendations of the Secretary for modifications

38443 to Federal law (including regulations) relating to the

38444 importation of live dogs, including for the protection of public

38445 health.

38446

38447 (c) Provision of Information.--To facilitate the preparation of the

38448report submitted under subsection (a), not later than 180 days after the

38449date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce, the Secretary

38450of Health and Human Services, and the Secretary of Homeland Security

38451shall each provide to the Secretary of Agriculture all available data

38452and information relating to the importation of live dogs into the United

38453States, including--

38454 (1) the data described in paragraphs (1) through (4) of

38455 subsection (b) for each of the 3 most recent calendar years for

38456 which data is available; and

38457 (2) any recommendations for modifications to Federal law

38458 (including regulations) relating to the importation of live

38459 dogs, including for the protection of public health.

38460SEC. 12510. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 25 USC 4301 note.&gt;&gt; TRIBAL PROMISE ZONES.

38461

38462 (a) In General.--In this section, the term ``Tribal Promise Zone''

38463means an area that--

38464

38465[[Page 132 STAT. 4991]]

38466

38467 (1) is nominated by 1 or more Indian tribes (as defined in

38468 section 4(13) of the Native American Housing Assistance and

38469 Self-Determination Act of 1996 (25 U.S.C. 4103(13))) for

38470 designation as a Tribal Promise Zone (in this section referred

38471 to as a ``nominated zone'');

38472 (2) has a continuous boundary; and

38473 (3) the Secretary designates as a Tribal Promise Zone, after

38474 consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, the Secretary of

38475 Education, the Attorney General, the Secretary of the Interior,

38476 the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the Secretary of

38477 Health and Human Services, the Secretary of Labor, the Secretary

38478 of the Treasury, the Secretary of Transportation, and other

38479 agencies as appropriate.

38480

38481 (b) Authorization and Number of Designations.--Not later than 1 year

38482after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall nominate a

38483minimum number of nominated zones, as determined by the Secretary in

38484consultation with Indian tribes, to be designated as Tribal Promise

38485Zones.

38486 (c) Period of Designations.--

38487 (1) In general.--The Secretary shall designate nominated

38488 zones as Tribal Promise Zones before January 1, 2020.

38489 (2) Effective dates of designations.--The designation of any

38490 Tribal Promise Zone shall take effect--

38491 (A) for purposes of priority consideration in

38492 Federal grant programs and initiatives (other than this

38493 section), upon execution of the Tribal Promise Zone

38494 agreement with the Secretary; and

38495 (B) for purposes of this section, on January 1 of

38496 the first calendar year beginning after the date of the

38497 execution of the Tribal Promise Zone agreement.

38498 (3) Termination of designations.--The designation of any

38499 Tribal Promise Zone shall end on the earlier of--

38500 (A)(i) with respect to a Tribal Promise Zone not

38501 described in paragraph (4), the end of the 10-year

38502 period beginning on the date that such designation takes

38503 effect; or

38504 (ii) with respect to a Tribal Promise Zone described

38505 in paragraph (4), the end of the 10-year period

38506 beginning on the date the area was designated as a

38507 Tribal Promise Zone before the date of the enactment of

38508 this Act; or

38509 (B) the date of the revocation of such designation.

38510 (4) Application to certain zones already designated.--In the

38511 case of any area designated as a Tribal Promise Zone by the

38512 Secretary before the date of the enactment of this Act, such

38513 area shall be deemed a Tribal Promise Zone designated under this

38514 section (notwithstanding whether any such designation has been

38515 revoked before the date of the enactment of this Act) and shall

38516 reduce the number of Tribal Promise Zones remaining to be

38517 designated under paragraph (1).

38518

38519 (d) Limitations on Designations.--No area may be designated under

38520this section unless--

38521 (1) the entities nominating the area have the authority to

38522 nominate the area of designation under this section;

38523 (2) such entities provide written assurances satisfactory to

38524 the Secretary that the competitiveness plan described in the

38525 application under subsection (e) for such area will be

38526 implemented and that such entities will provide the Secretary

38527 with

38528

38529[[Page 132 STAT. 4992]]

38530

38531 such data regarding the economic conditions of the area (before,

38532 during, and after the area's period of designation as a Tribal

38533 Promise Zone) as the Secretary may require; and

38534 (3) the Secretary determines that any information furnished

38535 is reasonably accurate.

38536

38537 (e) Application.--No area may be designated under this section

38538unless the application for such designation--

38539 (1) demonstrates that the nominated zone satisfies the

38540 eligibility criteria described in subsection (a); and

38541 (2) includes a competitiveness plan that--

38542 (A) addresses the need of the nominated zone to

38543 attract investment and jobs and improve educational

38544 opportunities;

38545 (B) leverages the nominated zone's economic

38546 strengths and outlines targeted investments to develop

38547 competitive advantages;

38548 (C) demonstrates collaboration across a wide range

38549 of stakeholders;

38550 (D) outlines a strategy that connects the nominated

38551 zone to drivers of regional economic growth; and

38552 (E) proposes a strategy for focusing on increased

38553 access to high quality affordable housing and improved

38554 public safety.

38555

38556 (f) Selection Criteria.--

38557 (1) In general.--From among the nominated zones eligible for

38558 designation under this section, the Secretary shall designate

38559 Tribal Promise Zones on the basis of--

38560 (A) the effectiveness of the competitiveness plan

38561 submitted under subsection (e) and the assurances made

38562 under subsection (d);

38563 (B) unemployment rates, poverty rates, vacancy

38564 rates, crime rates, and such other factors as the

38565 Secretary may identify, including household income,

38566 labor force participation, and educational attainment;

38567 and

38568 (C) other criteria as determined by the Secretary.

38569 (2) Minimal standards.--The Secretary may set minimal

38570 standards for the levels of unemployment and poverty that must

38571 be satisfied for designation as a Tribal Promise Zone.

38572SEC. 12511. PRECISION AGRICULTURE CONNECTIVITY.

38573

38574 (a) Findings.--Congress finds the following:

38575 (1) Precision agriculture technologies and practices allow

38576 farmers to significantly increase crop yields, eliminate overlap

38577 in operations, and reduce inputs such as seed, fertilizer,

38578 pesticides, water, and fuel.

38579 (2) These technologies allow farmers to collect data in real

38580 time about their fields, automate field management, and maximize

38581 resources.

38582 (3) Studies estimate that precision agriculture technologies

38583 can reduce agricultural operation costs by up to 25 dollars per

38584 acre and increase farm yields by up to 70 percent by 2050.

38585 (4) The critical cost savings and productivity benefits of

38586 precision agriculture cannot be realized without the

38587 availability of reliable broadband Internet access service

38588 delivered to the agricultural land of the United States.

38589 (5) The deployment of broadband Internet access service to

38590 unserved agricultural land is critical to the United States

38591

38592[[Page 132 STAT. 4993]]

38593

38594 economy and to the continued leadership of the United States in

38595 global food production.

38596 (6) Despite the growing demand for broadband Internet access

38597 service on agricultural land, broadband Internet access service

38598 is not consistently available where needed for agricultural

38599 operations.

38600 (7) The Federal Communications Commission has an important

38601 role to play in the deployment of broadband Internet access

38602 service on unserved agricultural land to promote precision

38603 agriculture.

38604

38605 (b) Task Force.--

38606 (1) Definitions.--In this subsection:

38607 (A)(i) The term ``broadband Internet access

38608 service'' means a mass-market retail service by wire or

38609 radio that provides the capability to transmit data to,

38610 and receive data from, all or substantially all Internet

38611 endpoints, including any capabilities that are

38612 incidental to, and enable the operation of, the

38613 communications service, but excluding dial up internet

38614 access service.

38615 (ii) Such term includes any service the Commission

38616 finds to be providing a functional equivalent of the

38617 service described in clause (i).

38618 (B) The term ``Commission'' means the Federal

38619 Communications Commission.

38620 (C) The term ``Department'' means the Department of

38621 Agriculture.

38622 (D) The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of

38623 Agriculture.

38624 (E) The term ``Task Force'' means the Task Force for

38625 Reviewing the Connectivity and Technology Needs of

38626 Precision Agriculture in the United States established

38627 under paragraph (2).

38628 (2) Establishment.--Not later than 1 year after the date of

38629 enactment of this Act, the Commission shall establish the Task

38630 Force for Reviewing the Connectivity and Technology Needs of

38631 Precision Agriculture in the United States.

38632 (3) Duties.--

38633 (A) In general.--The Task Force shall consult with

38634 the Secretary, or a designee of the Secretary, and

38635 collaborate with public and private stakeholders in the

38636 agriculture and technology fields to--

38637 (i) identify and measure current gaps in the

38638 availability of broadband Internet access service

38639 on agricultural land;

38640 (ii) develop policy recommendations to promote

38641 the rapid, expanded deployment of broadband

38642 Internet access service on unserved agricultural

38643 land, with a goal of achieving reliable

38644 capabilities on 95 percent of agricultural land in

38645 the United States by 2025;

38646 (iii) promote effective policy and regulatory

38647 solutions that encourage the adoption of broadband

38648 Internet access service on farms and ranches and

38649 promote precision agriculture;

38650 (iv) recommend specific new rules or

38651 amendments to existing rules of the Commission

38652 that the Commission should issue to achieve the

38653 goals and purposes of the policy recommendations

38654 described in clause (ii);

38655

38656[[Page 132 STAT. 4994]]

38657

38658 (v) recommend specific steps that the

38659 Commission should take to obtain reliable and

38660 standardized data measurements of the availability

38661 of broadband Internet access service as may be

38662 necessary to target funding support, from future

38663 programs of the Commission dedicated to the

38664 deployment of broadband Internet access service,

38665 to unserved agricultural land in need of broadband

38666 Internet access service; and

38667 (vi) recommend specific steps that the

38668 Commission should consider to ensure that the

38669 expertise of the Secretary and available farm data

38670 are reflected in future programs of the Commission

38671 dedicated to the infrastructure deployment of

38672 broadband Internet access service and to direct

38673 available funding to unserved agricultural land

38674 where needed.

38675 (B) No duplicate data reporting.--In performing the

38676 duties of the Commission under subparagraph (A), the

38677 Commission shall ensure that no provider of broadband

38678 Internet access service is required to report data to

38679 the Commission that is, on the day before the date of

38680 enactment of this Act, required to be reported by the

38681 provider of broadband Internet access service.

38682 (C) Hold harmless.--The Task Force and the

38683 Commission shall not interpret the phrase ``future

38684 programs of the Commission'', as used in clauses (v) and

38685 (vi) of subparagraph (A), to include the universal

38686 service programs of the Commission established under

38687 section 254 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C.

38688 254).

38689 (D) Consultation.--The Secretary, or a designee of

38690 the Secretary, shall explain and make available to the

38691 Task Force the expertise, data mapping information, and

38692 resources of the Department that the Department uses to

38693 identify cropland, ranchland, and other areas with

38694 agricultural operations that may be helpful in

38695 developing the recommendations required under

38696 subparagraph (A).

38697 (E) List of available federal programs and

38698 resources.--Not later than 180 days after the date of

38699 enactment of this Act, the Secretary and the Commission

38700 shall jointly submit to the Task Force a list of all

38701 Federal programs or resources available for the

38702 expansion of broadband Internet access service on

38703 unserved agricultural land to assist the Task Force in

38704 carrying out the duties of the Task Force.

38705 (4) Membership.--

38706 (A) In general.--The Task Force shall be--

38707 (i) composed of not more than 15 voting

38708 members who shall--

38709 (I) be selected by the Chairman of

38710 the Commission, in consultation with the

38711 Secretary; and

38712 (II) include--

38713 (aa) agricultural producers

38714 representing diverse geographic

38715 regions and farm sizes,

38716 including owners and operators

38717 of farms of less than 100 acres;

38718 (bb) an agricultural

38719 producer representing tribal

38720 agriculture;

38721

38722[[Page 132 STAT. 4995]]

38723

38724 (cc) Internet service

38725 providers, including regional or

38726 rural fixed and mobile broadband

38727 Internet access service

38728 providers and telecommunications

38729 infrastructure providers;

38730 (dd) representatives from

38731 the electric cooperative

38732 industry;

38733 (ee) representatives from

38734 the satellite industry;

38735 (ff) representatives from

38736 precision agriculture equipment

38737 manufacturers, including drone

38738 manufacturers, manufacturers of

38739 autonomous agricultural

38740 machinery, and manufacturers of

38741 farming robotics technologies;

38742 (gg) representatives from

38743 State and local governments; and

38744 (hh) representatives with

38745 relevant expertise in broadband

38746 network data collection,

38747 geospatial analysis, and

38748 coverage mapping; and

38749 (ii) fairly balanced in terms of technologies,

38750 points of view, and fields represented on the Task

38751 Force.

38752 (B) Period of appointment; vacancies.--

38753 (i) In general.--A member of the Committee

38754 appointed under subparagraph (A)(i) shall serve

38755 for a single term of 2 years.

38756 (ii) Vacancies.--Any vacancy in the Task

38757 Force--

38758 (I) shall not affect the powers of

38759 the Task Force; and

38760 (II) shall be filled in the same

38761 manner as the original appointment.

38762 (C) Ex-officio member.--The Secretary, or a designee

38763 of the Secretary, shall serve as an ex-officio,

38764 nonvoting member of the Task Force.

38765 (5) Reports.--Not later than 1 year after the date on which

38766 the Commission establishes the Task Force, and annually

38767 thereafter, the Task Force shall submit to the Chairman of the

38768 Commission a report, which shall be made public not later than

38769 30 days after the date on which the Chairman receives the

38770 report, that details--

38771 (A) the status of fixed and mobile broadband

38772 Internet access service coverage of agricultural land;

38773 (B) the projected future connectivity needs of

38774 agricultural operations, farmers, and ranchers; and

38775 (C) the steps being taken to accurately measure the

38776 availability of broadband Internet access service on

38777 agricultural land and the limitations of current, as of

38778 the date of the report, measurement processes.

38779 (6) Termination.--The Commission shall renew the Task Force

38780 every 2 years until the Task Force terminates on January 1,

38781 2025.

38782

38783 (c) No Additional Funds Authorized.--No additional funds is

38784authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section. This section

38785shall be carried out using amounts otherwise authorized.

38786SEC. 12512. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 5856.&gt;&gt; IMPROVEMENTS TO UNITED STATES

38787 DROUGHT MONITOR.

38788

38789 (a) In General.--The Secretary shall coordinate with the Director of

38790the National Drought Mitigation Center and the

38791

38792[[Page 132 STAT. 4996]]

38793

38794Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to

38795enhance the collection of data to improve the accuracy of the United

38796States Drought Monitor.

38797 (b) Utilization.--To the maximum extent practicable, the Secretary

38798shall utilize a consistent source or sources of data for programs that

38799are based on drought or precipitation indices, such as the livestock

38800forage disaster program established under section 1501(c) of the

38801Agricultural Act of 2014 (7 U.S.C. 9081(c)) or policies or plans of

38802insurance established under the Federal Crop Insurance Act (7 U.S.C.

388031501 et seq.).

38804 (c) Review.--Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of

38805this Act, the Secretary shall conduct a review of--

38806 (1) the types of data currently utilized by the United

38807 States Drought Monitor;

38808 (2) the geographic coverage and density of existing data

38809 collection sites; and

38810 (3) other meteorological or climatological data that is

38811 being collected by other Federal agencies, State and local

38812 governments, and non-Federal entities that could be utilized by

38813 the United States Drought Monitor.

38814

38815 (d) Improvements.--

38816 (1) In general.--Upon the completion of the review

38817 prescribed in subsection (c), the Secretary shall--

38818 (A) seek to expand the collection of relevant data

38819 in States or geographic areas where coverage is

38820 currently lacking as compared to other States or

38821 geographic areas; and

38822 (B) to the maximum extent practicable, develop

38823 standards to allow the integration of meteorological or

38824 climatological data into the United States Drought

38825 Monitor derived from--

38826 (i) in-situ soil moisture profile measuring

38827 devices;

38828 (ii) citizen science (as defined in the

38829 Crowdsourcing and Citizen Science Act (15 U.S.C.

38830 3724)), including data from the Cooperative

38831 Observer Program of the National Weather Service;

38832 and

38833 (iii) other Federal agencies, State and local

38834 governments, and non-Federal entities.

38835 (2) Authorization of appropriations.--There is to be

38836 authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary to carry out this

38837 subsection $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 through

38838 2023.

38839SEC. 12513. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 1632d.&gt;&gt; DAIRY BUSINESS INNOVATION

38840 INITIATIVES.

38841

38842 (a) Definitions.--In this section:

38843 (1) Dairy business.--The term ``dairy business'' means a

38844 business that develops, produces, markets, or distributes dairy

38845 products.

38846 (2) Initiative.--The term ``initiative'' means a dairy

38847 product and business innovation initiative established under

38848 subsection (b).

38849

38850 (b) Establishment.--The Secretary shall establish not less than 3

38851regionally-located dairy product and business innovation initiatives for

38852the purposes of--

38853 (1) diversifying dairy product markets to reduce risk and

38854 develop higher-value uses for dairy products;

38855

38856[[Page 132 STAT. 4997]]

38857

38858 (2) promoting business development that diversifies farmer

38859 income through processing and marketing innovation; and

38860 (3) encouraging the use of regional milk production.

38861

38862 (c) Selection of Initiatives.--An initiative--

38863 (1) shall be positioned to draw on existing dairy industry

38864 resources, including activities conducted by the National Dairy

38865 Promotion and Research Board and other dairy promotion entities,

38866 research capacity, academic and industry expertise, a density of

38867 dairy farms or farmland suitable for dairying, and dairy

38868 businesses; and

38869 (2) may serve a certain product niche, such as specialty

38870 cheese, or serve dairy businesses with dairy products derived

38871 from the milk of a specific type of dairy animal, including

38872 dairy products made from cow milk, sheep milk, and goat milk.

38873

38874 (d) Entities Eligible To Host Initiative.--

38875 (1) In general.--Subject to paragraph (2), any of the

38876 following entities may submit to the Secretary an application to

38877 host an initiative:

38878 (A) A State department of agriculture or other State

38879 entity.

38880 (B) A nonprofit organization.

38881 (C) An institution of higher education.

38882 (D) A cooperative extension service.

38883 (2) Capacity of eligible entity.--Any entity described in

38884 subparagraphs (A) through (D) of paragraph (1) shall be eligible

38885 to submit an application under that paragraph if the entity

38886 has--

38887 (A) a capacity to provide consultation and expertise

38888 necessary to advance the purpose and activities of the

38889 proposed initiative; and

38890 (B) expertise in grant distribution and tracking.

38891 (3) Ineligible entity.--A dairy promotion program shall not

38892 be eligible to host an initiative under this section.

38893

38894 (e) Partners.--

38895 (1) In general.--An entity described in subsection (d)(1)

38896 may establish as a partner an organization or entity described

38897 in paragraph (2)--

38898 (A) prior to the submission of the application under

38899 that subsection; or

38900 (B) after approval of the application, in

38901 consultation with the Secretary.

38902 (2) Partner described.--A partner under paragraph (1) shall

38903 be an organization or entity with expertise or experience in

38904 dairy, including the marketing, research, education, or

38905 promotion of dairy.

38906

38907 (f) Activities of Initiatives.--

38908 (1) Direct assistance to dairy businesses.--An initiative

38909 shall provide nonmonetary assistance directly to dairy

38910 businesses through private consultation or widely available

38911 distribution--

38912 (A) by the entity that hosts the initiative under

38913 subsection (d)(1);

38914 (B) through contracting with industry experts;

38915 (C) through the provision of technical assistance,

38916 such as informational websites, webinars, conferences,

38917 trainings, plant tours, and field days; or

38918

38919[[Page 132 STAT. 4998]]

38920

38921 (D) through research institutions, including

38922 cooperative extension services.

38923 (2) Types of assistance.--Eligible forms of assistance

38924 include--

38925 (A) business consulting, including business plan

38926 development for processed dairy products, strategic

38927 planning assistance, and distribution and supply chain

38928 innovation;

38929 (B) marketing and branding assistance, including

38930 market messaging, packaging innovation, consumer

38931 assessments, innovation in emerging market

38932 opportunities, and evaluation of regional, national, and

38933 international markets;

38934 (C) assistance in product innovation, including the

38935 development of value-added products, innovation in

38936 byproduct reprocessing and use maximization, and dairy

38937 product production training, including in new, rare, or

38938 innovative techniques; and

38939 (D) other nonmonetary assistance, as determined by

38940 the Secretary.

38941 (3) Grants to dairy businesses.--

38942 (A) In general.--An initiative shall provide grants

38943 on a competitive basis to new and existing dairy

38944 businesses for the purposes of--

38945 (i) modernization, specialization, and grazing

38946 transition on dairy farms;

38947 (ii) value chain and commodity innovation and

38948 facility and process updates for dairy processors;

38949 and

38950 (iii) product development, packaging, and

38951 marketing of dairy products.

38952 (B) Grants to certain entities.--An initiative may

38953 provide a grant on a noncompetitive basis to an entity

38954 that receives assistance under paragraph (1) to advance

38955 the business activities recommended as a result of that

38956 assistance.

38957 (C) Grant amounts.--Grants provided under this

38958 paragraph shall not exceed $500,000, unless a greater

38959 amount is approved by the Secretary.

38960 (4) Consultation.--An entity that hosts an initiative shall

38961 consult with the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board,

38962 the Secretary, and the Administrator of the Agricultural

38963 Marketing Service in carrying out the initiative.

38964 (5) Conflict of interest.--

38965 (A) In general.--The Secretary shall establish

38966 guidelines and procedures to prevent any conflict of

38967 interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest by

38968 an initiative (including a partner of the initiative)

38969 during the allocation of direct assistance under

38970 paragraph (1) or grant funding under paragraph (3).

38971 (B) Penalty.--The Secretary may suspend or terminate

38972 an initiative if the initiative (including a partner of

38973 the initiative) is found to be in violation of the

38974 guidelines and procedures established under subparagraph

38975 (A).

38976

38977 (g) Distribution of Funds.--

38978 (1) In general.--Using the funds made available to carry out

38979 this section, the Secretary--

38980

38981[[Page 132 STAT. 4999]]

38982

38983 (A) shall provide not less than 3 awards to eligible

38984 entities described in subsection (d) for the purposes of

38985 carrying out the activities under subsection (f); and

38986 (B) is encouraged to award funds under subparagraph

38987 (A) in multiyear funding allocations.

38988 (2) Use of funds.--Not less than 50 percent of the funds

38989 made available under subsection (i) shall be allocated to grants

38990 under subsection (f)(3).

38991 (3) Priority.--An entity hosting an initiative shall give

38992 priority to the provision of direct assistance under subsection

38993 (f)(1) and grants under subsection (f)(3) to--

38994 (A) dairy farms and dairy businesses with limited

38995 access to other forms of assistance;

38996 (B) employee-owned dairy businesses;

38997 (C) cooperatives; and

38998 (D) dairy businesses that seek to create dairy

38999 products that add substantial value in processing or

39000 marketing, such as specialty cheeses.

39001 (4) Requirement.--Assistance or a grant shall not be made

39002 available to a foreign person making direct investment (as those

39003 terms are defined in section 801.2 of title 15, Code of Federal

39004 Regulations (or successor regulations)) in the United States in

39005 the case of--

39006 (A) direct assistance under subsection (f)(1) that

39007 is provided to a specific dairy business and is not

39008 publicly available, as determined by the Secretary; or

39009 (B) a grant under subsection (f)(3).

39010 (5) Supplementation.--To the extent practicable, the

39011 Secretary shall ensure that funds provided to an initiative

39012 supplement, and do not duplicate or replace, existing dairy

39013 product research, development, and promotion activities.

39014

39015 (h) Report.--Not later than January 31, 2022, the Secretary shall

39016submit to Congress a report on the outcomes of the program under this

39017section and any related activities and opportunities to further increase

39018dairy innovation.

39019 (i) Authorization of Appropriations.--There is authorized to be

39020appropriated to carry out this section $20,000,000 for each fiscal year.

39021SEC. 12514. REPORT ON FUNDING FOR THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD

39022 AND AGRICULTURE AND OTHER EXTENSION

39023 PROGRAMS.

39024

39025 (a) In General.--Not later than 2 years after the date on which the

39026census of agriculture required to be conducted in calendar year 2017

39027under section 2 of the Census of Agriculture Act of 1997 (7 U.S.C.

390282204g) is released, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on

39029Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the Committee on

39030Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report that

39031describes the funding necessary to adequately address the needs of the

39032National Institute of Food and Agriculture, activities carried out under

39033the Smith-Lever Act (7 U.S.C. 341 et seq.), and research and extension

39034programs carried out at an 1890 Institution (as defined in section 2 of

39035the Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act of 1998

39036(7 U.S.C. 7601)) or an institution designated under the Act of July 2,

390371862 (commonly known as the ``First Morrill Act'') (12 Stat. 503,

39038chapter 130; 7 U.S.C. 301 et seq.), to provide adequate services for the

39039

39040[[Page 132 STAT. 5000]]

39041

39042growth and development of the economies of rural communities based on

39043the changing demographic in the rural and farming communities in the

39044various States.

39045 (b) Requirements.--In preparing the report under subsection (a), the

39046Secretary shall focus on the funding needs of the programs described in

39047subsection (a) with respect to carrying out activities relating to small

39048and diverse farms and ranches, veteran farmers and ranchers, value-added

39049agriculture, direct-to-consumer sales, and specialty crops.

39050SEC. 12515. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 2160.&gt;&gt; PROHIBITION ON SLAUGHTER OF

39051 DOGS AND CATS FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION.

39052

39053 (a) In General.--Except as provided in subsection (c), no person

39054may--

39055 (1) knowingly slaughter a dog or cat for human consumption;

39056 or

39057 (2) knowingly ship, transport, move, deliver, receive,

39058 possess, purchase, sell, or donate--

39059 (A) a dog or cat to be slaughtered for human

39060 consumption; or

39061 (B) a dog or cat part for human consumption.

39062

39063 (b) Scope.--Subsection (a) shall apply only with respect to

39064conduct--

39065 (1) in or affecting interstate commerce or foreign commerce;

39066 or

39067 (2) within the special maritime and territorial jurisdiction

39068 of the United States.

39069

39070 (c) Exception for Indian Tribes.--The prohibition in subsection (a)

39071shall not apply to an Indian (as defined in section 4 of the Indian

39072Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C. 5304))

39073carrying out any activity described in subsection (a) for the purpose of

39074a religious ceremony.

39075 (d) Penalty.--Any person who violates subsection (a) shall be

39076subject to a fine in an amount not greater than $5,000 for each

39077violation.

39078 (e) Effect On State Law.--Nothing in this section--

39079 (1) limits any State or local law or regulation protecting

39080 the welfare of animals; or

39081 (2) prevents a State or unit of local government from

39082 adopting and enforcing an animal welfare law or regulation that

39083 is more stringent than this section.

39084SEC. 12516. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 21 USC 343 note.&gt;&gt; LABELING EXEMPTION FOR

39085 SINGLE INGREDIENT FOODS AND PRODUCTS.

39086

39087 The food labeling requirements under section 403(q) of the Federal

39088Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 343(q)) shall not require that

39089the nutrition facts label of any single-ingredient sugar, honey, agave,

39090or syrup, including maple syrup, that is packaged and offered for sale

39091as a single-ingredient food bear the declaration ``Includes X g Added

39092Sugars.''.

39093SEC. 12517. SOUTH CAROLINA INCLUSION IN VIRGINIA/CAROLINA PEANUT

39094 PRODUCING REGION.

39095

39096 Section 1308(c)(2)(B)(iii) of the Farm Security and Rural Investment

39097Act of 2002 (7 U.S.C. 7958(c)(2)(B)(iii)) is amended by striking

39098``Virginia and North Carolina'' and inserting ``Virginia, North

39099Carolina, and South Carolina''.

39100

39101[[Page 132 STAT. 5001]]

39102

39103SEC. 12518. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 16 USC 1725b.&gt;&gt; FOREST SERVICE HIRE

39104 AUTHORITY.

39105

39106 (a) In General.--The Secretary of Agriculture may appoint, without

39107regard to the provisions of subchapter I of chapter 33 of title 5,

39108United States Code, other than sections 3303 and 3328 of such title, a

39109qualified candidate described in subsection (b) directly to a position

39110with the Department of Agriculture, Forest Service for which the

39111candidate meets Office of Personnel Management qualification standards.

39112 (b) Qualifications.--Subsection (a) applies to a former resource

39113assistant (as defined in section 203 of the Public Land Corps Act (16

39114U.S.C. 1722)) who--

39115 (1) completed a rigorous internship with a land managing

39116 agency, such as the Forest Service Resource Assistant Program;

39117 (2) successfully fulfilled the requirements of the

39118 internship program; and

39119 (3) earned an undergraduate or graduate degree from an

39120 accredited institution of higher education (as defined in

39121 section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C.

39122 1001)).

39123

39124 (c) Limitation.--The direct hire authority under this section may

39125not be exercised with respect to a specific qualified candidate after

39126the end of the 2-year period beginning on the date on which the

39127candidate completed the undergraduate or graduate degree, as the case

39128may be, or has successfully fulfilled the requirements of the internship

39129program, whichever is later.

39130SEC. 12519. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 2279j.&gt;&gt; CONVERSION AUTHORITY.

39131

39132 The Secretary may, notwithstanding subchapter I of chapter 33 of

39133title 5, United States Code, governing appointments in the competitive

39134or excepted service, noncompetitively convert to an appointment in the

39135competitive service, in an agency or office within the Department of

39136Agriculture, a recent graduate or student who is a United States citizen

39137and has been awarded and successfully completed a scholarship program

39138granted to the individual by the Department through the 1890 National

39139Scholars Program or the 1994 Tribal Scholars Program carried out by the

39140Department, provided the individual meets the requirements for such

39141conversion and meets Office of Personnel Management qualification

39142standards, as determined by the Secretary. Nothing in the preceding

39143sentence shall be construed as requiring the Secretary to convert an

39144individual under the authority under such sentence.

39145SEC. 12520. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 7 USC 2279k.&gt;&gt; AUTHORIZATION OF PROTECTION

39146 OPERATIONS FOR THE SECRETARY OF

39147 AGRICULTURE AND OTHERS.

39148

39149 (a) In General.--The Department of Agriculture is authorized to

39150employ qualified law enforcement officers or special agents to provide--

39151 (1) protection for the Secretary and the Deputy Secretary

39152 during the performance of official duties by each such officer

39153 and during any activity that is preliminary or postliminary to

39154 the performance of official duties by each such officer;

39155 (2) protection, incidental to the protection provided

39156 pursuant to paragraph (1), to an individual accompanying each

39157 such officer who is participating in an activity or event

39158 relating to the official duties of each such officer when there

39159 is an articulable threat to such individual;

39160 (3) continuous protection to the Secretary and Deputy

39161 Secretary (including during periods not described in paragraph

39162

39163[[Page 132 STAT. 5002]]

39164

39165 (1)) if there is an articulable threat of physical harm, in

39166 accordance with guidelines established by the Secretary; and

39167 (4) protection of another senior officer representing the

39168 Secretary (including a person nominated to be the Secretary

39169 during the pendency of such nomination) if there is an

39170 articulable threat of physical harm, in accordance with

39171 guidelines established by the Secretary.

39172

39173 (b) Authorities of the Protective Operation.--

39174 (1) In general.--The Secretary may authorize officers or

39175 special agents employed pursuant to subsection (a)--

39176 (A) to carry firearms;

39177 (B) to conduct criminal investigations into

39178 potential threats to the security of persons protected

39179 under this section;

39180 (C) to make arrests without a warrant for any

39181 offense against the United States committed in the

39182 presence of such officer or special agent;

39183 (D) to perform protective intelligence work,

39184 including identifying and mitigating potential threats

39185 and conducting advance work to review security matters

39186 relating to sites and events; and

39187 (E) to coordinate with local law enforcement

39188 agencies.

39189 (2) Guidelines.--The authority conveyed under this section

39190 shall be exercised in accordance with any--

39191 (A) guidelines issued by the Attorney General; and

39192 (B) such additional guidelines as may be issued by

39193 the Secretary.

39194

39195 (c) Exception.--The authorities granted under this section may be

39196exercised notwithstanding section 1343(b)(1) of title 31, United States

39197Code.

39198 (d) Report.--Not later than September 30, 2019, and each September

3919930 through 2024, the Secretary shall provide to the Committee on

39200Agriculture of the House of Representatives and Committee on

39201Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report describing

39202the protection provided, and accounting for the expenditures made,

39203pursuant to this section.

39204

39205 PART II--NATIONAL OILHEAT RESEARCH ALLIANCE

39206

39207SEC. 12531. NATIONAL OILHEAT RESEARCH ALLIANCE.

39208

39209 (a) In General.--Section 713 of the National Oilheat Research

39210Alliance Act of 2000 (42 U.S.C. 6201 note; Public Law 106-469) is

39211amended by striking ``18 years'' and inserting ``28 years''.

39212 (b) Limitation on Obligations of Funds.--The National Oilheat

39213Research Alliance Act of 2000 (42 U.S.C. 6201 note; Public Law 106-469)

39214is amended by inserting after section 707 the following:

39215``SEC. 708. LIMITATION ON OBLIGATION OF FUNDS.

39216

39217 ``(a) In General.--In each calendar year of the covered period, the

39218Alliance may not obligate an amount greater than the sum of--

39219 ``(1) 75 percent of the amount of assessments estimated to

39220 be collected under section 707 in that calendar year;

39221 ``(2) 75 percent of the amount of assessments actually

39222 collected under section 707 in the most recent calendar year

39223

39224[[Page 132 STAT. 5003]]

39225

39226 for which an audit report has been submitted under section

39227 706(f)(2)(B) as of the beginning of the calendar year for which

39228 the amount that may be obligated is being determined, less the

39229 estimate made pursuant to paragraph (1) for that most recent

39230 calendar year; and

39231 ``(3) amounts permitted in preceding calendar years to be

39232 obligated pursuant to this subsection that have not been

39233 obligated.

39234

39235 ``(b) Excess Amounts Deposited in Escrow Account.--Assessments

39236collected under section 707 in excess of the amount permitted to be

39237obligated under subsection (a) in a calendar year shall be deposited in

39238an escrow account for the duration of the covered period.

39239 ``(c) Treatment of Amounts in Escrow Account.--

39240 ``(1) In general.--During the covered period, the Alliance

39241 may not obligate, expend, or borrow against amounts required

39242 under subsection (b) to be deposited in the escrow account.

39243 ``(2) Interest.--Any interest earned on amounts described in

39244 paragraph (1) shall be--

39245 ``(A) deposited in the escrow account; and

39246 ``(B) unavailable for obligation for the duration of

39247 the covered period.

39248

39249 ``(d) Release of Amounts in Escrow Account.--Beginning on October 1,

392502028, the Alliance may withdraw and obligate any amount in the escrow

39251account.

39252 ``(e) Covered Period Defined.--In this section, the term `covered

39253period' means the period that begins on February 6, 2019, and ends on

39254September 30, 2028.''.

39255 (c) Conforming Amendments.--The National Oilheat Research Alliance

39256Act of 2000 (42 U.S.C. 6201 note; Public Law 106-469) is amended--

39257 (1) in section 706(d)(1), by striking ``not exceed 7 percent

39258 of the amount of assessments collected in any calendar year,

39259 except that during the first year of operation of the Alliance

39260 such expenses and amounts shall not exceed 10 percent of the

39261 amount of assessments'' and inserting ``not exceed 7 percent of

39262 the amount of assessments collected in any calendar year that

39263 are permitted to be obligated in that calendar year''; and

39264 (2) in section 707--

39265 (A) in subsection (e), by inserting ``that are

39266 permitted to be obligated'' after ``amount of

39267 assessments collected in the State'' each place it

39268 appears; and

39269 (B) in subsection (f), by inserting ``and permitted

39270 to be obligated'' after ``assessments collected'' each

39271 place it appears.

39272

39273 Subtitle F--General Provisions

39274

39275SEC. 12601. &lt;&lt;NOTE: 16 USC 704 note.&gt;&gt; BAITING OF MIGRATORY GAME

39276 BIRDS.

39277

39278 (a) Definitions.--In this section:

39279 (1) Normal agricultural operation.--The term ``normal

39280 agricultural operation'' has the meaning given the term in

39281 section 20.11 of title 50, Code of Federal Regulations (as in

39282 effect on the date of enactment of this Act).

39283 (2) Post-disaster flooding.--The term ``post-disaster

39284 flooding'' means the destruction of a crop through flooding

39285

39286[[Page 132 STAT. 5004]]

39287

39288 in accordance with practices required by the Federal Crop

39289 Insurance Corporation for agricultural producers to obtain crop

39290 insurance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act (7 U.S.C. 1501 et

39291 seq.) on land on which a crop was not harvestable due to a

39292 natural disaster (including any hurricane, storm, tornado,

39293 flood, high water, wind-driven water, tidal wave, tsunami,

39294 earthquake, volcanic eruption, landslide, mudslide, drought,

39295 fire, snowstorm, or other catastrophe that is declared a major

39296 disaster by the President in accordance with section 401 of the

39297 Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act

39298 (42 U.S.C. 5170)) in the crop year--

39299 (A) in which the natural disaster occurred; or

39300 (B) immediately preceding the crop year in which the

39301 natural disaster occurred.

39302 (3) Rice ratooning.--The term ``rice ratooning'' means the

39303 agricultural practice of harvesting rice by cutting the majority

39304 of the aboveground portion of the rice plant but leaving the

39305 roots and growing shoot apices intact to allow the plant to

39306 recover and produce a second crop yield.

39307

39308 (b) Regulations to Exclude Rice Ratooning and Post-disaster

39309Flooding.--Not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this

39310Act, the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary

39311of Agriculture, shall revise part 20 of title 50, Code of Federal

39312Regulations, to clarify that rice ratooning and post-disaster flooding,

39313when carried out as part of a normal agricultural operation, do not

39314constitute baiting.

39315 (c) Reports.--Not less frequently than once each year--

39316 (1) the Secretary of Agriculture shall submit to the

39317 Secretary of the Interior a report that describes any changes to

39318 normal agricultural operations across the range of crops grown

39319 by agricultural producers in each region of the United States in

39320 which the official recommendations described in section 20.11(h)

39321 of title 50, Code of Federal Regulations (as in effect on the

39322 date of enactment of this Act), are provided to agricultural

39323 producers; and

39324 (2) the Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the

39325 Secretary of Agriculture and after seeking input from the heads

39326 of State departments of fish and wildlife or the Regional

39327 Migratory Bird Flyway Councils of the United States Fish and

39328 Wildlife Service, shall publicly post a report on the impact

39329 that rice ratooning and post-disaster flooding have on the

39330 behavior of migratory game birds that are hunted in the area in

39331 which rice ratooning and post-disaster flooding, respectively,

39332 have occurred.

39333SEC. 12602. PIMA AGRICULTURE COTTON TRUST FUND.

39334

39335 Section 12314 of the Agricultural Act of 2014 (7 U.S.C. 2101 note;

39336Public Law 113-79) is amended--

39337 (1) by striking ``2018'' each place it appears and inserting

39338 ``2023'';

39339 (2) by striking ``calendar year 2013'' each place it appears

39340 and inserting ``the prior calendar year'';

39341 (3) in subsection (b)(2)--

39342 (A) by redesignating subparagraphs (A) and (B) as

39343 clauses (i) and (ii), respectively;

39344

39345[[Page 132 STAT. 5005]]

39346

39347 (B) in the matter preceding clause (i) (as so

39348 redesignated), by striking ``(2) Twenty-five'' and

39349 inserting the following:

39350 ``(2)(A) Except as provided in subparagraph (B), twenty-

39351 five'';

39352 (C) in subparagraph (A)(ii) (as so designated), by

39353 striking ``subparagraph (A)'' and inserting ``clause

39354 (i)''; and

39355 (D) by adding at the end the following:

39356 ``(B)(i) A yarn spinner shall not receive an amount under

39357 subparagraph (A) that exceeds the cost of pima cotton that--

39358 ``(I) was purchased during the prior calendar year;

39359 and

39360 ``(II) was used in spinning any cotton yarns.

39361 ``(ii) The Secretary shall reallocate any amounts reduced by

39362 reason of the limitation under clause (i) to spinners using the

39363 ratio described in subparagraph (A), disregarding production of

39364 any spinner subject to that limitation.'';

39365 (4) in subsection (c)--

39366 (A) in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by

39367 striking ``(b)(2)(A)'' and inserting ``(b)(2)(A)(i)'';

39368 (B) in paragraph (2), by striking ``and'' at the

39369 end;

39370 (C) in paragraph (3), by striking the period at the

39371 end and inserting ``; and''; and

39372 (D) by adding at the end the following:

39373 ``(4) the dollar amount of pima cotton purchased during the

39374 prior calendar year--

39375 ``(A) that was used in spinning any cotton yarns;

39376 and

39377 ``(B) for which the producer maintains supporting

39378 documentation.'';

39379 (5) in subsection (e)--

39380 (A) in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by

39381 striking ``by the Secretary--'' and inserting ``by the

39382 Secretary not later than March 15 of the applicable

39383 calendar year.''; and

39384 (B) by striking paragraphs (1) and (2); and

39385 (6) in subsection (f), by striking ``subsection (b)--'' in

39386 the matter preceding paragraph (1) and all that follows through

39387 ``not later than'' in paragraph (2) and inserting ``subsection

39388 (b) not later than''.

39389SEC. 12603. AGRICULTURE WOOL APPAREL MANUFACTURERS TRUST FUND.

39398 (I) in the matter preceding clause

39399 (i), by striking ``the payment--'' and

39400 inserting ``the payment, payments in

39401 amounts authorized under that

39402 paragraph.''; and

39403 (II) by striking clauses (i) and

39404 (ii); and

39405 (ii) in subparagraph (B)--

39406

39407[[Page 132 STAT. 5006]]

39408

39409 (I) in the matter preceding clause

39410 (i), by striking ``4002(c)--'' and

39411 inserting ``4002(c), payments in amounts

39412 authorized under that paragraph.''; and

39413 (II) by striking clauses (i) and

39414 (ii); and

39415 (B) in paragraph (2), by striking ``submitted--'' in

39416 the matter preceding subparagraph (A) and all that

39417 follows through ``to the Secretary'' in subparagraph (B)

39418 and inserting ``submitted to the Secretary''; and

39419 (3) in subsection (c)--

39421 striking ``subsection (b)--'' and inserting ``subsection

39422 (b) not later than April 15 of the year of the

39423 payment.''; and
